It's a very fun horror platformer with cool graphics, which mostly requires you to solve simple puzzles and survive occasional escape action sequences. When I say 'platformer', it actually has a 3D presentation and some depth, but the structure is dominantly 2D with rooms to the right & left where you must often climb or sometimes get to another floor. You can interact with many objects in a physics sim-like environment. It's very well polished, varied, and convincing.

The controls are OK on K+M settings; I had to remap them a couple of times to be comfortable with them. The problem is that you need to constantly press on a key to remain crouched, run, or climb, so it can get annoying after a while, especially since you have to perform other actions at the same time. Overall, it's very satisfying despite a very few frustrating puzzles that rely on agility alone or repetition until you understand what the game's expecting from you.

There's no real story. You stumble through the rooms of a strange boat as a tiny child who tried to escape while avoiding the bad guys. There are some slightly disturbing horror scenes, but nothing over the top. In fact, it's a curious and unique mix of innocence and horror.

The game isn't long; you can finish it in about 4 hours. There's a little replay value if you want to get all the achievements.

I highly recommend The Hideaway DLC, which offers an even more interesting and fun experience, but you can skip the 2 other ones.

This is the Best game out of all of the genre: Limbo, Inside, Little Nightmares. Every Chapter has it's own theme and every single one nails the feeling of Dread and Desperation your character (probably) experiences. And it all concludes with such a high-art dramatic ending, giving the watcher a satisfaction of the work they witnessed. Without the music, which is masterful, it would not have such an impact. Truly a masterpiece, a work of art, I dare to say it is the best horror game I have played/watched and one of the best works in the horror genre in general.

Not a bad little game. 

Not much of a story to tell, just  basically a little girls nightmares. It's a short game, could be completed on a first run in about 3-5 hours tops. The graphics are cartoon-like but are nice. The creatures in the nightmares are weird and ugly lol. The replay value is there if you want to get the rest of the Steam Achievements. Wouldn't recommend the regular price of $20, so definitely get it while it is on sale. Haven't played the second yet and supposedly #3 is coming out this year (2024). I wouldn't say there are jump scares in the game, but there are some heart pounding "run for your life" moments.

Little Nightmares is a captivating and eerie puzzle-platformer game that immerses players in a dark and twisted world. The game's atmospheric visuals and haunting soundtrack create a chilling and immersive experience. The protagonist, a young girl named Six, navigates through a series of nightmarish environments, solving puzzles and avoiding terrifying enemies.

The game's art style is both beautiful and unsettling, with detailed environments and grotesque characters that contribute to the game's overall sense of dread. The gameplay is challenging and requires players to use stealth and cunning to survive the game's various threats.

Little Nightmares excels at creating a sense of unease and tension, as players are constantly on edge, never knowing what horrors await them around the next corner. The game's narrative is minimal but effectively conveys a sense of mystery and intrigue.

Overall, Little Nightmares is a must-play for fans of atmospheric horror games. Its unique art style, engaging gameplay, and spine-tingling atmosphere make it a standout title in the genre.
ITS A VERY CHALLENGING GAME. BUT IT;'S INCREDIBLY WELL PUT TOGETHER AND FUN TO PLAY. DEFINITELY RECOMMEND A TRY FOR ANYONE WHO HASN'T PLAYED IT YET.  TOTALLY WORTH IT, EVEN IF YOU RAGE A LITTLE BIT.
yo

This game saved my life.

I am 25.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline broken. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Little Nightmares is a must-play for fans of atmospheric horror and immersive storytelling. With its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and spine-tingling atmosphere, it's a game that will stay with you long after the credits roll. So dim the lights, crank up the volume, and prepare to embark on a chilling adventure through the shadows.Whether you're tiptoeing past a towering chef or hiding from the watchful gaze of a grotesque janitor, every moment is infused with a palpable sense of dread. Yet, beneath the horror lies a deeper narrative that explores themes of innocence lost and the darkness that lurks within us all. The environments are dripping with atmosphere, from the dimly lit corridors of the Maw to the grotesque inhabitants that inhabit its halls. Each scene is a masterpiece in its own right, immersing you in a world that feels both familiar and deeply unsettling.

This is a platformer game, so expect a lot of parkour. It's also clearly designed for play with console-style controllers. The whole reason I play PC games is to use a mouse & keyboard, so you can imagine my frustration when I say the controls are AWFUL in that regard.. Barely playable. These two aspects should have been listed on the sales page, hence my negative review to warn potential buyers.

Aside from that the graphics, ambiance, and story were quite wonderful. Disappointed overall.

You get to a section where there are enemies swarming you and are on a time crunch and gameplay becomes go through the same little section and die each time until u figure out the right action to move on to next section. Like a video stuck on replay. Whatever atmosphere, visual design, or story the game is going for DIES, and quite quickly at that, everytime this happens. The controls are nonsensical and clunky, like hold one button to move while holding one button to sprint while holding one button to crouch whiel holding one button so you dont drop what yoiu are carrying. FUN. No option to make those toggle like the lighter, you also dont grab ledges automatically you have to press the interact button to grab and edge. No indication something is an edge you can grab either and the game allows your character to move towards background and foreground. So at times you will die because you tried to grab an edge and were too close to the wrong "ground" or will take you longer to solve a puzzle because you had the right instinct as to what was intractable but the clunkiness made you think it wasn't something interactable. FUN.

The ability to move you camera is pretty useless, requiring precision on the y axis when the camera is at a fucked angle is also pretty trash. The game made itself 2.5D for no reason, I don't see it expressed gameplay wise in any meaningful way that isn't an absolute chore or a clunky mess. Also zero explanations, which isn't completely terrible in sections where you are not on a time crunch, otherwise pretty frustrating. If I have mentioned more negative things than good is becasue so far these have made a bigger impression on me than anything else in the "game."

Checkpoints dont make a whole lot of sense in how far back they set you. I'm already smelling a "our-game-is-really-short-so-we-artificially-extended-it-with-poor/none-checkpoint-placement" type situation. Ok so changing keybindings sometimes causes your character to not respond. Like if i make 0 on number pad my crouch/slide it will let you crouch but not slide, so i have to keep it at default. Really milking game time, cant skip the 20min credits at the end.

Finished game. Good stage/enemy design, they are pretty unique, overall it is average. Would be an exellent game with the aforementioned issues fixed. The story is a little loose, very short game probably like 3 hours without all the trial and error and fighting the controls. 

All in all I do like it, cant recommend it for more than a $5-7 sale though.

This game is a lot of fun. The art design and atmosphere is really where this game shines. It's a dark and dingy (slightly Tim burton-esque) side(ish) scroller, very entertaining. The only thing is that I got a bit bored in the middle section. It may just be me, but I felt like the different sections weren't different enough from each other to keep me interested. All that is with the exception of the end section. This is where the "horror" really kicks in, and keeps up till the dramatic, head-scratching conclusion. The DLC is also a very good inclusion, feels very similar to the game, yet different enough to be entertaining. Not my favorite but still worth a playthrough, 6.5/10

[h1]There is no darkness so dense, so menacing, or so difficult that it cannot be overcome by light.[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]This review is based on playing on the Steam deck.[/b]
Little Nightmares is a 3D platforming adventure from a 2D perspective that encourages the player to step outside of their comfort zones and unlock their imagination to complete its many challenges and puzzles.
But do you have what it takes to help Six escape The Maw, or is she doomed to be trapped forever?

[table]
[tr]
    [th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
    [th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
    [td]🟩 The story has been thoughtfully plotted out and written to give the player freedom to speculate on many aspects of the plot, but a solid foundation to work from.

🟩 Each chapter feels fresh and unique on its own, demonstrating excellent level design and the ability to implement multiple unique experiences into one.

🟩 The visual experience is a little dated but in no way unpleasant, especially while playing it on the Steam Deck. The audio has aged much better, providing an intense atmosphere and solid and gritty animation sounds that will have you gritting your teeth with every moment.[/td]
    [td]🟥 The movement mechanics are frustratingly clunky.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
In Little Nightmares, you take control of Six, a young girl who awakens in a panic after a startling dream about a tall, thin woman standing in thick shadow, who slowly turns to realise her.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3143300160

With Six dragging herself from her bed, you are tasked with helping her escape The Maw that has become her home. Complete puzzles while being pursued by the many residents who wish to seek Six harm, evade your pursuers and help her attain the freedom she desires.

Little Nightmares is a wonderfully designed story experience that is captivatingly innocent and ruthlessly dark, all in a seamless brushstroke. By capturing a tangible yearning to escape the confines forced upon you, this game illustrates a true struggle to survive in its absolute primal form, employing your childhood fears and uncomfortable settings to throw you off and forcing you to question whether the next step will be your last.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]A game of cat and mouse.[/h3]
Six has very little in her favour aboard The Maw. She is small, unarmed and weak to the many horrors that seek her demise. Even in the aspects you would believe would be on her side, such as speed and agility, she still falls short compared to them. The only real option you have to keep her safe is to keep her hidden by hiding in the shadows and embracing claustrophobic tunnels.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3143300269

A task often made difficult by the fact the movement controls are a touch cumbersome and often make it challenging to manoeuvre as you seek your escape.

Thankfully, exploration doesn't play a large part in the experience here, so you won't have to go far off the beaten track often to find items or collectibles.

[h3]Use your head.[/h3]
The only other significant aspect of this game is the puzzle mechanics. There are quite a few puzzles in Little Nightmares that will challenge you to complete multiple steps for your reward or have you try and achieve objectives while being hunted.

These can be quite difficult to overcome, but the reward for your prowess and ingenuity will be your freedom.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
As mentioned above, Little Nightmares does suffer from somewhat dated graphics, but it is far from a terrible visual experience. The journey is still extremely captivating and atmospheric, and it plays like it’s right at home on the deck.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3143300584

The audio hasn't aged as much and remains a solid experience throughout the journey. Animation sounds will have you gritting your teeth against the abrasive sounds you commit to, and the general ambience of the world helps immerse you wholly. The music is also sensational by providing compelling and unique tracks for each new location you visit.

[h1]Deck Performance and Specifications[/h1]
I experienced no issues running Little Nightmares on the deck, and the general performance was well above expectations. A full charge allowed approximately 3-4 hours of gameplay at the default graphical settings.

[h1]Final Thoughts - Very Good[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
With so much going for it, Little Nightmares is probably paramount one of the best deck experiences I've had to date. Its beautiful storyline, and wonderful world building consistently impressed me, and I'm still entangled in the complex plot it left me with. Only weighed down by its incredibly clunky movement mechanics, which take up a large portion of the experience. This is definitely a must play game for fans of horrific atmosphere and gripping tales.

[quote]If a nightmare has driven you from your slumber and you seek refuge against the horrors of this world, head to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43064204/] Hell, Purgatory and Paradise[/url] to light a fire that will provide you true salvation against the darkness.[/quote]

In Little Nightmares 1, i've dedicated 12 hours of gameplay, which speaks volumes about the game's ability to engage and hold my attention. The game's primary strength lies in its atmospheric and haunting visuals, which create an eerie and mysterious world that is both unsettling and captivating. The attention to detail in the environment and character design is commendable, immersing players in a nightmarish journey through the Maw—a surreal underwater vessel that serves as the game's setting.
The gameplay mechanics are intuitive yet challenging, requiring you to solve intricate puzzles while navigating through treacherous environments. The game cleverly balances exploration, stealth, and platforming elements, keeping you on your toes as you encounter various grotesque and formidable enemies. The suspenseful gameplay combined with the game's ominous soundtrack creates a sense of constant tension, making each encounter a heart-pounding experience.
Moreover, the narrative of Little Nightmares 1 is minimalistic yet intriguing. It relies on visual storytelling, leaving much to the player's interpretation. As you progress, you unravel the dark secrets of the Maw, slowly piecing together the unsettling history behind its inhabitants and the protagonist, Six. This narrative approach adds a layer of mystery and invites players to contemplate the deeper meaning behind the events they witness. 9/10

Very disappointed. Visually impressive, atmospheric and the gameplay design has a lot of cool ideas. But the control and the camera were unresponsive and confusing. The lack of story made me alternatively feel bored or frustrated to the point where playing was a chore and I had no reason to continue except I've paid for this. I died a lot of times confused about where a platform was,  my character was trapped in a wall walking in the darkness until I had to reload the checkpoint, collisions failed a lot of times killing you, especially in the eye areas. The solution for some puzzles was so scripted that you have to try the exact place a few times until it worked. Sometimes the solution didn't work the first time and let me thinking that i was doing it wrong and wasted a lot of my time.  Going back and forth to the checkpoints for things like those was annoying AF. I was very worried about how the next stages could be even worse when I had to be fast with the terrible camera and control when the game decided to spare me more suffering and crashed with the U4 atlas window. Got better things to do.

On the outside chance you’ve found your way here and are yet to play the game, I’d strongly encourage you to pick it up and give it a go. This one is worth the full price, and the developers certainly deserve the support, as they’ve created something that will live in the memory for far more time than it takes to complete, and that, perhaps more than anything else, is the hallmark of great horror.

What a gorgeous masterpiece...

The atmosphere is so intense, mysterious and fascinating:
Sounds, lighting, mist, colors, a world really comes to life and it literally feels as if you are there strolling around these mysterious, scary places, driven by your curiosity and will to survive.

I love the use of ambient sounds in this game. There are occasional melodies here and there, but most of the time it's just you and the cracking of planks of woods you walk on, the wind blowing and the distant echoes that fill this amazing world. It really is something that should be seen more in videogames.

Moving around and getting your way out of trouble felt so engaging:
swinging while holding onto chains/levers, activating mechanisms, picking up stuff, bringing it with you all the way to the point of use, taking advantage of objects/environment to distract monsters...

I have never seen  such attention to detail before in a videogame: the animations of Six while she interacts with her surroundings are so expressive (she goes as far as raising and sliding her hands on the walls if you walk close to them).

The character designs are truly spooky and the whole setting was pouring with magic. The inspiration from titles like Ghibli's Spirited Away are very apparent.
The final boss felt incredible to take down, and the ending delivers one of the best climaxes I have ever seen in any form of media.

It'll be unlikely to feel an experience as slow and intense as this one again.

Yoooo! What a blast! As someone who loves a good puzzler game, this is a must have! Highly recommended for fans of Nihilumbra, Feist, Closure, Inside, and (obviously) Limbo. I'm sure it's just as good. Took me 17 hours to beat the game and all the challenges except the hardest one which requires you to beat the whole game without dying in under an hour. Overall I played this game for almost a full 24 hours, very frustrating at times but so rewarding when completing the challenges. Highly recommended, 5/5!

This franchise will always be one of my top favorites, I wish it had more attention! 
The overall atmosphere and character design is beautiful and creepy. The environmental horror and use of space in this game has always been a pleasurable experience to me, even if the first game's level design is a bit bleak at the beginning in comparison to Little Nightmares II. Still, the concept of the Maw and interpretative lore is something I always come back to, I will never get sick of the theories people have on this game. The soundtrack is always MWAH! ♥ Six's theme rings in my head forever - and several zone related music. Little Nightmares II wins on chase music, imo.

- If you're looking for a game that's easy on horror and most of the fear is running for your life, this is that game. I would say that alone can be nerve wracking, but in a typical style of horror it isn't that. Which is good for me, I'm a baby.
- I wouldn't say this game is... too hard? You might die a few times in chases or mechanics but they aren't hard to grapple with unless the finicky character movement gets you. Also, I'd recommend a controller, always.
- This game is half the time of Little Nightmares II, you can complete it in a matter of a few hours.
- DLCs are definitely worth it, buy the bundle.

Little Nightmares is a game that I would absolutely recommend to folks that enjoyed Playdead's Inside. Inside was my appetizer into suspenseful, side-scrolling horror games, and Little Nightmares was a lovely first course follow-up. Little Nightmares was very similar in that it offered limited or absent dialogue or directly stated narrative. Both games tell a story in their environments and characters, although Little Nightmares leaves less to the imagination. The characters are horrifying and creative and strike a fear that quickly turns into determination to conquer. What we learn about the our protagonist throughout the game is delightful and intriguing, and left me wanting to learn more about the other games in the series. The game itself, while being home to deeply disturbing concepts, is executed GORGEOUSLY. I found myself continually saying "This game is beautiful," which felt odd because of its macabre atmosphere. Although it's suggested to play this game on a controller, it is possible to play with a keyboard. The controls are basic, but suddenly seem more difficult with a grotesque creature breathing down your neck. The gameplay was seamless and I encountered zero bugs throughout my two-session playthrough. The puzzles and situations the player is faced with are so creative, and I found myself wondering what they would come up with next. If you enjoy a little suspense, excellent world-building, and being morbidly curious, this is an excellent game for you.

I played this game on the PC with my keyboard, but I found it a bit frustrating and sometimes had to reload simply due to key issues. I would highly recommend playing with a controller. Otherwise, I changed some keys, and I felt that the following changes significantly improved control for me.

Change to the following:
Sprint -> Right shift
Grab -> Right ctrl
Crouch -> Left shift

Mary Berry’s slow roast leg of lamb with ratatouille

Ingredients
large leg of lamb, or shoulder, bone in, approx 2kg/4lb 8oz
3 tbsp chopped fresh thyme
1 tbsp paprika
2 tbsp olive oil
2 garlic cloves, sliced into slivers
3 onions, thickly sliced
2 red peppers, chopped into large pieces
1 large aubergine, chopped into large pieces
400g tin chopped tomatoes
300ml/½ pint beef or chicken stock
2 tbsp sun-dried tomato paste
3 fresh bay leaves
1 tbsp honey
salt and freshly ground black pepper

Method
Preheat the oven to 220C/200C Fan/Gas 7.

Using a small sharp knife, make a series of small slits over the leg of lamb. Put 2 tablespoons of the thyme in a bowl with the paprika and oil, season and mix together. Spread the mixture over the lamb, insert the garlic slivers into the slits and season the lamb with salt and pepper. Put the onions into a large, deep roasting tin, sit the lamb on top and roast for about 40 minutes.

Reduce the oven temperature to 160C/140C Fan/Gas 3.

Scatter the peppers and aubergine around the lamb. Pour the tomatoes into a bowl, add the stock, tomato paste, the remaining thyme, bay leaves and honey, and stir to combine. Pour into the tin over the peppers and stir. Cover the whole tin with foil and return to the oven for about 4 hours, until the lamb is tender and falling off the bone.

Lift the lamb out of the tin and place on a large board. Spoon off any fat from the top of the sauce. Carve the meat into slices and serve with the vegetables.

"Little Nightmares" is a captivating and atmospheric puzzle-platformer that immerses players in a hauntingly beautiful yet eerie world. The game's unique art style and sound design create a tense and unsettling atmosphere that perfectly complements its mysterious narrative. As players guide the small protagonist, Six, through a series of disturbing environments, they'll encounter clever puzzles and face off against grotesque enemies. The game's emphasis on stealth and environmental storytelling adds to its overall charm, making it a memorable and chilling experience. With its well-crafted ambiance and engaging gameplay, "Little Nightmares" stands out as a noteworthy addition to the horror and puzzle genres, offering a captivating journey that lingers long after the credits roll.

Immersive game, amazing audio, great lighting and simple puzzles. Puzzles did progressively get slightly harder and sometimes I was stuck on what to do, but eventually found my way. Love that the game wasn't too punishing if you die or get caught, since you start over at the most recent checkpoint. This fits my casual play-style. It's probably a 3-4 hour completion for most people. The ending was shocking to say the least, but you can feel the child's character development as the game goes on even though there were no words spoken. My one wish would be that the puzzles would of had more variety and more interaction with the environment. Very few objects were moveable and often were the same in different rooms. Can't wait to play LN2 & 3!

I absolutely love the story and mystery of Little Nightmares, the vibes and animation style are so creepy. Though there were some problems with the controls / perspective, the game is still one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. The puzzles themselves weren't too difficult, but there were a couple that made me stop and think for a while. This game is full of platforming, puzzles, mystery, and stealth (unfortunately for my death counter, as I suck at stealth in games), so if you like those, check it out! 

There is a lot of gore, violence, and just super creepy things in general, so if that's not your cup of tea then this game probably isn't for you. However, in terms of fright, I would say this game isn't too scary. I get scared by the simplest things and still rank this as one of my favorite puzzle games, so that says something.

"Little Nightmares: My Impressions of This Masterful Game"

<3
Here's my impression of the game "Little Nightmares" after a brief but captivating gameplay experience.

"Little Nightmares" is a true embodiment of art in the world of video games. From the first moments of the game, you are captivated by an atmosphere of mystery and suspense. The game not only evokes fear but also creates a unique world where every step is a new discovery.

The graphics impress with their detail, atmosphere, and uniqueness. Each character and level has its own character and contributes to the overall mood of the game. The variety of tasks and puzzles keeps you on edge, and the music and sound design create a unique soundtrack to your adventure.

The gameplay is a separate narrative. Agility and logical thinking are crucial, and each level requires new skills and strategies. It's not just a game; it's interactive art that captivates your imagination and leaves you with plenty of impressions.

In "Little Nightmares," I found not just a game but an emotional and intellectual challenge. It's a work of art that will leave its mark in the memory of every player. And what particularly impresses me is the game's soundtrack, resembling a lullaby at night. The musical accompaniment in "Little Nightmares" seamlessly fits into the overall mood of the game and, like a lullaby, has the ability to immerse you in deep reflection, creating a sense of calm even amid horrors and mysteries.

Each melodic touch, adapted to the atmosphere of a specific level or moment in the game, resonates in my inner world, adding even more emotional nuance to the events. This musical approach emphasizes not only the terrifying side of the story but also makes it more profound and emotionally rich.

The soundtrack of "Little Nightmares" gives the impression of being in a large, living dream, where melodies intertwine with the visual aesthetics of the game, creating an incredibly harmonious and effective interactive experience. This lullaby symphony becomes an integral part of the impressions from "Little Nightmares" and enhances the overall gaming experience, making it even more unforgettable.

I both love and hate Little Nightmares. If it wasn't so damn clunky and frustrating in its controls and bugs, it would be one of my favorite games of all time.

The environments and art direction are absolutely stunning--it's an absolute delight to look at despite its grotesque themes. The character designs are simultaneously disturbing and oddly charming, in a sort of Studio Ghibli's "Spirited Away" sort of way. The animations are fantastic--from the twitches of limbs, to the swinging of loose doors you climb, to the way the fish's bodies reacts to your mass as you walk over them--every little detail really helps to make this world feel alive. Despite the incredible, dark atmosphere however, Little Nightmares never really felt like a horror game. I wouldn't go in expecting to be spooked.

The game is less than two hours in length, which wouldn't be a bad thing in itself, but the final chapter didn't feel like much of a climax. It was way too rushed. You're presented with a new monster (the least interesting of them all) who's been hinted at throughout the game, but you have one brief chase sequence with it before a very simple final fight.

The worst part of the game, unfortunately, is the flow. You will most likely die to something that felt out of your control, maybe multiple times in a row. Near the beginning for example, you're taught to keep quiet to avoid a monster. You transition to a new room while being silent. He follows you in and immediately chases you as if he heard you, despite there being no indication (not even tense music).

The hurtboxes feel inaccurate. I died way too many times to collisions with enemies when I was clearly out of their reach. I must've died to the dining table level at least seven times, which completely kills any sort of tension. I've run into multiple bugs where I got stuck on the environment or an item disappeared and I had to reload.

So basically I wholeheartedly recommend the game. I just wish it had been perfected. It's one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen, just incredibly frustrating.

Beautiful game! Very atmospheric, got a very eerie feeling to it. I especially love the dream-like structures: objects that looks normal at a first glance, but on a closer look e.g the proportions make no sense. Really feels like a nightmare! That been said, this is no scary game. There are some unexpected events but they are not scary. That's cool for me, I usually can't handle that.

Now there's one thing that's very bad designed in this game: the controller vibrations. For literally every move that the character makes, there's a vibration. First of all this is annoying, and it cannot be disabled in the game settings. Secondly, there are parts in the game where they really make sense -- for example, matching the heartbeat in tense situations. But they have little to no effect, because you are already saturated...
Highly recommend playing! I am currently collecting all the achievements and made the purchase for the second game. Just a really great franchise and single-player game.

This is one of the only horror games I have ever played, and I absolutely loved it. Introduced to the series by Markiplier some years ago, I played Little Nightmares 2 blind and was blown away. So much so that I came back and bought the original installment AND its DLC just to show my support for the franchise. I even got to play the DLC blind, and while the final few puzzles were a little bit of a roadblock on occasion, I don't regret sticking through it! The atmosphere, the grotesque imagery, the music, the tension! Before LN, I had made a point of only ever watching OTHERS play through horror games so I didn't have to, and yet even watching footage of the first game: I KNEW I wanted to play its sequel myself! Little Nightmares shies away from easy jumpscares and relies almost solely on atmosphere, imagery, and puzzles that make you do things your instincts really don't want you doing! It's oddly thrilling! Definitely worth picking up!

The levels themselves were challenging (maybe it's also because I'm new to gaming), but not to the point that you had to rage-quit. The fact that you have to complete little side quests (which, btw, the game does not tell you about) to get the various achievements adds value to the game.

I do think that this game was intended to be played with a controller, though, as, sometimes, Six would not respond accurately to the keyboard movements. So, if you have a controller, definitely try playing this game with it. 

One thing is for sure, I wanna get the rest of the series :)

Little Nightmares is an amazing experience, but the gameplay itself has some problems and can be frustrating. If you are interested in the game because of the vibe you get from screenshots or trailers then I can easily recommend it. If, however, you play games more for the mechanics and don't care as much about art, sound, or story, then you may want to read further.

First, before I list my complaints, let me praise the game a bit more so that it's clear how much I liked it. It really is an incredible experience. The graphics are fantastic; it uses Unreal, but the art direction really sets it apart from other Unreal games. Everything has a very tactile feel, so that every creepy place you venture through feels like you are there. The sound effects amplify the already disturbing visuals, with the noises that the inhabitants make deserving special recognition. Playing Little Nightmares did make me feel both like there was some kind of dream/nightmare logic going on as well as like I was a little kid in a big world that I didn't understand. There are some scary moments (including a few really tense standout moments), but I think my main impression looking back was of being unsettled, uneasy, disturbed, and curious. There is no dialog and nothing is explained, so if you enjoy "environmental storytelling" where you have to try and piece together what is happening then this will be right up your alley.

Ok, now for the bad: I had _many_ frustrations playing this game. It felt like the game design was often at odds with the incredible experience I was having, ruining my immersion and making me frustrated and just wanting to get past something to see what happened next.

The camera perspective is such that the gameplay is primarily 2D, with just a little bit of depth. I think this was the perfect choice visually, but the result is that it can be really challenging to accurately judge where your character is in the depth plane. This wouldn't be a problem except that the game has several sequences where this is critical. The classic example of this for me is when I was walking along a pipe, with no enemies or time pressure, and I just steered the character off, falling to her death. This was a one-time event, but there were many (MANY!) times when I missed a jump or didn't avoid dangerous obstacles I had to thread my way through, not because I didn't know what I was supposed to do or mistimed something but because I couldn't tell where I was in relation to other things.

In addition to these (presumably) unintentional issues, there are also intentional issues that are core parts of the game design that lead to frustration. There are many (MANY!) sequences where the required timing is really tight, but also you are given very little time to anticipate or react. The result of this is that I often found myself redoing sections over and over. To be clear, Little Nightmares is not a difficult game, and the skill required to actually complete any of these sections isn't so bad. The problem, though, is that it feels like failure is anticipated or forced; you often can't really know what to do ahead of time until you've tried it and seen what happens or how you fail. Even this isn't inherently bad (if a bit old school), but it is bad in the context of what Little Nightmares is trying to do in terms of mood. It sets up these incredible situations and set pieces where I as a player was 100% engaged and was completely identifying with my character, but then when I failed in that context and had to redo things multiple times they lost all effectiveness. In a game like Ori I think this kind of game design can work, because the focus is on skill and platforming, but in a game like Little Nightmares where the focus is on the tension and atmosphere it felt very counterproductive to me.
(Also, related side note: There is a section where the controls of the flashlight change suddenly and without warning (and with an onscreen hint if you die enough times that doesn't make it clear that the control scheme is actually different). If you decide to play and find yourself getting really frustrated at one point because of the flashlight, just remember that it may be behaving differently from how it has the entire game!)

Again, I loved this game! But it feels dishonest to recommend it without at least giving some disclaimers about how frustrated it made me at times. I can't say enough good things about the atmosphere and what an artistic achievement it is, and if you're willing to look past some gameplay flaws there is a remarkable and memorable experience to be had.
love this game

At the end of the day I liked this game, but there were portions of it that felt really annoying. It was mainly a game play and game design issue for me, everything else was spectacular. Tone, colors, grotesque and disturbing characters/plot, that's really what carried and sold the game for me.

But the game play and design...for goodness sake... a little bit of direction would have helped so as not to be lost all the time. I can not tell you how long it took me to realize I was supposed to climb up something, simply because the platform paths are not very "readable". On one hand, this is good for the immersion of the game - nothing really stands out all that much and it makes everything blend well together. On the other hand, you often find yourself trying again and again to figure out where you're supposed to go. 

I much prefer things like Mirror's edge's runner vision to show objects you can interact with or even GOW4's yellow painted cliffs/edges to show where to climb. I'm not saying make the paths you are supposed to platform super obvious like in GOW4 or in Mirror's Edge Runner vision, just that SOMETHING to indicate where to go or what to do would go a long way. It could even be something small like things falling to show there is more space above your area or to show a point of interest for the player. The strange depth perception, though unique and a positive trait of the game artistically, does add a layer of difficulty to platforming that can sometimes get frustrating. 

Now, there is also the evolution of the game play. Most games, they stay more or less the same throughout. Maybe you get new gear or learn a new move to keep things fresh as you progress, skill trees are examples of this since they add to the game without changing the overall game play. You'd still be punching, kicking, or casting spells... they just do different things now. But in this game, it kind of shifts into 4 genres and it does that pretty seamlessly. Each chapter is played differently from the next, the first is more like a stealth game, the second is more like a puzzle game, the third is a scrolling runner, and the last chapter is a boss battler. 

I personally had my gripes with this, though I do understand that it is a pretty cool concept to have your game change on you and then to suddenly adapt to the game's changes. (Inscryption is an example of this). The seamlessness of the genre transitions is what makes the game hard, even though it can be enjoyable. For example, after succeeding chapter 1, the stealth portion of the game, you move onto chapter 2 which deals more with puzzles and platforming. Because the way the game is played is now different in chapter 2, you realize that being really stealthy and playing things slow suddenly get you nowhere. In chapter 2, you are supposed to take big risks. This transition I actually did enjoy because both chapter 1 and chapter 2 felt like the same game. 

But come to chapter 3 and it felt like I was playing something different, even though it looked the same. In chapter 3, it is more of a runner-platformer. With far less puzzles, and where stealth is ultimately useless. This kind of felt like everything that I learned and the skills/tactics i developed in chapter 1/2 were pointless and thrown out the window. And so for me escaping chapter 2 felt more like the true ending since it rewarded all the work I did in both chapters. I was scared, disturbed, had adrenaline pumping, and then I was relieved. 

Then chapter 3 happened and I was deeply confused. I had no idea what the purpose of the game was anymore, no idea where I was going, why I was doing the things I was doing, and i had to shift from stealthy platforming puzzle solving tactics to ...running... and I did not feel rewarded after completing the chapter, I just really wanted it to be over because I got pretty frustrated and disheartened when it felt like nothing i learned in the past 2 hours of playing the game was working. It really felt like chapter 3 was only there for a major plot reveal so as to better tie in the story concept - which is already super vague. You can only build inferences on the story with subtle visuals followed by the 4-5 grotesque actions that take place.

I like when stories are like that, instead of huge lore dumps in a note or on the walls, you are allowed to fill in the spaces of the story yourself and it's pretty fun. Are they monsters? Aliens? what do they want with me? etc. If you are looking for something scary, this game is at most a 6/10 of being scary but a 11/10 at being disturbing.

[h1]Of the Maw or The hunger nightmare[/h1]

I confess that the platform game isn’t a type I usually play. But when I succeeded to go across the adventure from start to finish, it gave me a unique and fascinating experience. What is the game about? About a sympathetic character clothed in a yellow raincoat named Six, whose tenacity is to escape from the ship called the Maw.

I consider that has been reflected about the game and a variety of analyses have been written. I’ll only limit myself to describing something about the game and my experience in it.

The game expresses a story and it does so through a non-verbal narrative. All this is realized through its scenography. The elements that comprise a particular scene attain to convey a feeling and communicate a fragment of the story. As the players proceed, they discover the fullness of the narrative plot.

How does it accomplish to perform such non-verbal narration? The game does this through three components that, when put together, create something integral. These are: the soundtrack, the non-verbal narrative and the art. They all depend on each other. If one is missing, the essence of its plot will not be understood. Or, to talk about non-verbal narrative, it rest on art and music, for example.

[h1]The surrealism of flesh[/h1]

The game poses a developed problem, the meat-consuming society. The way the topic is approached is from the perspective of a tot. As the description of the game indicates: overcoming infanthood fears through a nightmarish journey in a world inhabited by corrupted souls. With this premise, the game forms its plot through psychological features where images, allegories, signs and symbols will preponderate. Everything it wants to tell is done in each scenario. The experience is visual, but also aural.

Although the criticism is outstanding, its art also attracts an attention. It's inevitable not to notice the artistic inspirations but it bring about to obtain an original and unique art. Surrealism mainly be conspicuous, although it coalesces with other artistic inclinations and expressions to achieve a grotesque horror scenography in an eclectic way.

It’s true that most of us have a prejudice about how we relate a scene to a work of art that we know. For me, for example, each scene forms a theatrical piece where the character Six is always in a performance. The progressive linear movement of each scene leads to a sequence like a piece of footage. The game is well composed that achieves to convey a message-feeling and, at the same time, an openness to personal understanding reflected in each immersive experience.

The enemies are symbolic and allegorical, deformed and grotesque creatures, causing an aesthetic experience and a unique sensation in the game. I’m impressed by the details. In particular, a feeling of being someone small in a place subjugated by colossal items. The feeling of repugnance, starving, fragility, helplessness and defencelessness is revealed at all times. All of this gives the immersive, uninterrupted experience, in the gameplay that’s seek and hide, as well as solving some small puzzles while dwelling inside the feeling of being caught, cornered or confined.

Although the gameplay is basic, where sometimes the options of running or hiding turn out to be discernible at all times, keeps our breath, fear and suspense by having ominous enemies consigned in our path. SFX, or special sounds, accentuate the tension experienced during such a moment, such as sounds of heartbeats or moans. In this way, the non-verbal narrative of the game is realized together.

[h1]The nightmare waltz[/h1]

I’ll say something briefly about the third component of the game's formula, its soundtrack. Tobias Lilja is its composer. Each piece of music expresses us about the happenings that the protagonist faces, mainly hunger, emptiness and the loss of her infantile.

The music performs the rhythm of the waltz, but takes it to dissimilar gradual tones, namely, light tones to dark tones. The drama of Six moving to the rhythm of the waves swinging the boat. Also it attempts to prove the ladder of Six's journey as presented in the start menu. It’s the ambiguous journey of a shadowy character to the bright peak.

The musical elements are often heard as lullabies but are distorted or deformed. It’s audible at all times and accentuates as a dramatic force in certain parts of the story. It’s ambient, industrial, with electronic music structures, but always focusing on conveying an enveloping atmosphere to each situation as a soundscape for the scenography.

It also relates the plot and, at the same time, affords an intensity to tense the feelings. Sometimes it’s luminous, but other times strident, screaming, strong, dark, funereal and hopeless. It has been realized well in the soundtrack, where it bares the distortion of the protagonist succumbing in a world where corrupted souls live. It’s an excellent piece of music to emphasize the nightmare.

[h1]Little Lost Things[/h1]

As a brief review I discern what I’ve noticed, although many details are absconding. I liked the metaphor, symbolism and allegory of the game, especially the way it begins and closes its plot. It’s beautiful with those opaque, murky and enigmatic tones in the style of surrealism and a drop of pictorial realism.

The game is a unique, original experience with a developed theme that is absorbing at all times. The game is short, but if you halt to contemplate every detail like me, you’ll be in for an agitating surprise. That is, the surrealism felt in the Maw. A world full of paradoxes and contradictions.

You’re unrestricted to imagine and understand what the game wants to say. There’re no theories, but rather a diversity of interpretations, which the game accomplishes to bring about that plurality of understandings and feelings experienced in a grotesque, terrifying, cruel and, paradoxically, beautifully disturbing world.

To complete the adventure, the game contains DLC that intercepts Six's plot. I personally didn't play the mini-game, as I consider [i]Little Nightmares[/i] to be an integrated plot and a complete game. There is no need to add even more to something that’s already well done. Recommended, it’s often on sale.

[h1]Recommendation: 9/10[/h1]

Despite the game crashing right before I could beat it, it is one of the most creepy horror games to date. Amazing atmosphere, and morbid story.

[b]PERSONAL RATING:[/b] 7.5/10

[b]GRAPHICS:[/b] Horrifying where they need to be, beautiful where they need to be. A genuinely unique and characteristic style that does exactly what it's meant to.
[b]CHARACTERS:[/b] There's no spoken dialogue in this game, so you won't be getting to know characters' personalities that way, but you grow fond of them regardless. I wanted to protect Six (and then I was proud of her, and then I was a little freaked out by her), the Lady is eerily beautiful, the Chefs are perfectly revolting, and the first time I saw the Janitor was a shock to the system in the best way possible in a horror game.
[b]GAMEPLAY:[/b] Controls can be a little finicky sometimes, but it was never enough to bother me -- only in the sense that some jumps may take a few tries to get the timing and angle right. I never found the 2.5D perspective unfair or misleading when it came to making leaps or deciphering where surfaces were, but a lot of people have complained about that so your mileage may vary; keep it in mind before you play.
[b]MULTIPLAYER:[/b] None.

Overall, I prefer the sequel story-wise, but this game has a little place in my heart. Additionally, note that the game only takes ~3 hours to complete, so I would personally feel a little cheated paying the current Steam price of £15.99 for it. I'd advise picking it up on sale.

I have honestly loved this game since i was younger and watching Dantdm play it the moment i found out about it.
I saw that it was on sale and thought 'hey, why not?' seeing as i had already borrowed the second game and gone in blind and had an absolute blast with it, getting every achievement.
At first, i had been annoyed by the pretty scuffed perspective and how easy it is to fall off platforms(compared to the sequel which also has some pretty annoying perspective at times) but, as i continued to play, I got more into it and way more used to it.
Odd to learn, easy to master, kind of a deal.

The narrative's ability to keep me captivated while also being very vague and puzzle-y is one of my favorite parts, especially when i can apply both literal and figurative theories to the game. Is this really happening? Is this just a child's perspective of the cruel world she lives in? Or is this truly about a child on a 'cruise' ship full of cannibals? It's all so interesting!
I do love the themes of innocence being crushed and molded into a rough bitterness just for Six to be able to survive, survival of the fittest and all that. It's a lot how our society handles child care, like with CPS and just blatant disrespect to even the idea of children.

Overall, very cool game and I am so excited for the 3rd game!

I thought I vividly remembered this game from various YouTube playthroughs I watched years ago so I didn't expect to discover anything disappointing when finally playing it myself. However, immediately after starting the game its awful keyboard and mouse controls caused a lot of frustration, this forced me to use one of my ps4 controllers. The controller solution worked most of the time, but I still found it to be imprecise, especially during a part of the final dlc where the player needs to aim at moving targets. The controls in this game are rough, given that the game is a 3d sidescroller where you need to coordinate movement with depth perception. Not sure how they would fix that though :<

I want to mention that the aesthetic and gameplay are inspired by two pieces of media in particular which I really love, the video game, Inside, and the film, Spirited Away. Little Nightmares is great in a lot of ways, traversing its interesting and well designed environments paired with awesome atmosphere and intimidating threats, you've got a very good game. Even though I didn't completely understand it's story, I was at least intrigued, and will probably watch some YouTube videos about it's story and lore later.

For a game that is loved this much i expected to be having a better time with it, but alas, little nightmares many strenghts get lost in frustration due to very poor controls, a lack of signposting/direction and unforgiving sections. It's a shame as the game looks and sounds amazing, the visuals and designs are all unique and memorable and the sound design is just right. Creaking doors and planks make way to terrifying screams belched out by horrendous abominations. The music is used sparringly but to great effect, especially in the rather memorable finale. Saddly the horrible controls leave much to be desired, such as getting stuck on little pieces of geometry at the worst possible time during a daring escape or failing countless jumps to the very poor depth perception. In fact depth perception or lack thereoff is a common occurance in this game, throwing an object at a button because you can't reach it is frustrating when it's this hard to get the direction right. All this things really add up to make the game feel clunky to play as a whole. It's also really unclear what to do or where to go at times. Since you can climb on some furniture but it isn't marked with a specific color or shine, so in a room with dozens of drawers you have to just guess which one you can climb. This is doubly annoying when you are running away from a monster, as these sequences are made to be very unforgiving, where even a moment's hesitation can get you killed. This took all the horror and terror out of these sequences and made them frustrating instead. I really hoped to like this game more, but in the end the audiovisual aspects aren't enough to alleviate the frustrations and the steep price that would make this game worth a purchase.

-- Cons --

A thin creature in a yellow hood, no taller than a chair leg, runs through a dark corridor, lifts a door key with both hands like a weight, and battles a lady in a kabuki mask... "Alice Through the Looking Glass". "Spirited Away". Childhood fairy tales and forgotten fears of the dark night.

It's not scary for you, but rather eerie. As if the scary stories that kids told each other at night became reality. Little Nightmares turns you into a child, briefly bringing back the psychology that you dealt with through books and scientific knowledge.

But you can't get rid of the experience you've gained - you still remain an adult, you reflect. You don't see danger in dark rooms. And this double vision effect, where you are both a child and an adult at the same time, creates a truly unique atmosphere in Little Nightmares.

An extremely thrilling and engaging game! The rush of adrenaline that flows through your body, the various surprises at each and every corner you turn, and the sensation of excitement when you finally figure out a puzzle or outsmart an enemy. If you love this game, which I'm sure you will, then you'll love the sequel even more!!

[h1][b]Overall, the game is decent, but due to its shortcomings, it left a negative impression on me.[/b][/h1]

[list]
[*]In terms of genre, Little Nightmares is a puzzle-platformer. However, one of the key aspects of this genre - controls - was not executed well enough. It's precisely because of the character's unresponsiveness that some sections become painfully difficult to complete. Often, the character gets stuck or jerks when interacting with the environment, and he is unresponsive and incredibly slow.

[*]In this game, deaths are probably one of the most unfair. In platforming sections or critical moments, the controls can be unreliable, and your character might not perform the necessary actions. Enemies aren't inherently dangerous, and they could be relatively easy to avoid, but sometimes it's really difficult to understand when they might notice you. Moreover, escaping from monsters is practically impossible, except when a hiding spot is immediately available, which isn't always the case. In such a case, it would be appropriate to have at least some way to escape, so that it wouldn't be a 100% death and level restart. For me, this just makes the stealth mechanics very annoying. Basically, it's not such a big problem, but it just adds extra inconvenience to an already too short game that's supposed to leave a positive impression.

[*]The environments, no matter how beautiful they are, are difficult to navigate. Due to the odd 2D/3D perspective, it's challenging to orient yourself in relation to your character's plane. When jumping onto a platform, you might find yourself slightly to the left or right of it. Interactive objects blend seamlessly with the environment and are easy to miss. There are many situations where you think you can climb somewhere, but it's actually impossible. This is especially frustrating in chase scenes, where you need to make quick decisions.

[*]At times, the static camera takes very inconvenient positions, making it impossible to understand your character's location. If something obstructs your view, you can't see your character, which is annoying. Strangely, the camera isn't tied to enemies, so there are instances where they can see you, but you can't. While you can move the camera using arrow keys (up-down-left-right), it's more of a crutch. Doing this consistently is difficult, primarily because of the control issues.

[*]Due to the size of the locations, you often have to run from one end to the other for a significant amount of time (and frustratingly, most puzzles involve finding keys or similar items on the opposite end of the map). Here, the problem also lies in the fact that solving such puzzles can be quite lingering, as they are not always intuitively clear.
[/list]

I believe these are the main reasons I personally didn't enjoy the game. I'm sure it has found its audience, and labeling it unplayable would be inaccurate. However, I found it difficult to get positive emotions by playing it, and this review is based on my personal experience.

[h3][i][b]P.S.[/b] In my review I considered the full game with 3 DLCs. So, if you disagree with certain points, it's possible that it might be related to the fact that you haven't experienced the additional game content.[/i][/h3]

Game still holds up in 2023. This game is demented and fun, albeit simple. The DLC really ties everything together, and I recommend getting them to complete the Little Nightmares experience. I'd even encourage you to play the DLC before the main story, and experience the horror for all it's worth. I've bought Little Nightmares 2, and downloaded the Little Nightmares comics, which I'm super excited to read. 

As a new-found achievement hunter, the achievements are totally accessible (except one). I got all the achievements and beat the game + DLCs in about 10 hours. However, it felt like 60 hours. Completing the achievements can be fun, and there do seem to be lore-related unlocks that you can only get through 100%-ing, but they aren't really explained. I have several scenes in my head that seemed significant, but I just don't understand the meaning. Now, my only complaint about the game is the achievement you unlock for completing the entire game in under 1 hour without dying. It's unreasonable, and just not fun. I didn't feel rewarded for completing it, I just felt desperate to get it done. 

Game is a 9/10, and seems to be heavily inspired by Spirited Away and Coraline — which adds to the dark coziness of this game.

Little Nightmares captivated me from start, the game's incredible world and intricate level design kept me impressed, while its story left me pondering long after I put down the controller. The blend of suspenseful gameplay and clever puzzles made for an unforgettable experience that lingers in my thoughts. A must-play for anyone who enjoys a unique and chilling adventure.

[h1]Little Nightmares[/h1]
[i]Diminutive Frightmares[/i]

[b]Little Nightmares[/b] is an enthralling and atmospheric puzzle-platformer that will leave players spellbound with its hauntingly unique visuals and eerie ambience. Developed by Tarsier Studios, this indie gem takes players on a macabre journey through a nightmarish world that's both unsettling and captivating.

Visually, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] shines. The art style is reminiscent of a Tim Burton movie, with its gloomy and grotesque character designs and intricately detailed environments. The attention to detail in the game's design is commendable, immersing players in a foreboding atmosphere that feels like a living nightmare. The use of lighting and shadows adds to the overall haunting experience, making every moment visually stunning and memorable.

The game's storyline is shrouded in mystery, which works to its advantage. Players control Six, a small, vulnerable protagonist who must navigate through the twisted halls of The Maw – a vast, derelict vessel inhabited by sinister and grotesque creatures. The lack of exposition allows players to unravel the narrative at their own pace, keeping them engaged and eager to discover the secrets hidden within the game's world.

Gameplay-wise, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] excels in creating a tense and suspenseful experience. Players must rely on their wits and stealth to avoid danger and solve environmental puzzles. The sense of vulnerability and helplessness is palpable, amplifying the fear factor and adrenaline rush as players stealthily evade the pursuing monstrosities. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenging puzzles and nerve-wracking encounters, keeping players on their toes throughout the adventure.

The sound design deserves special mention for enhancing the game's chilling atmosphere. The haunting melodies and spine-chilling sound effects further immerse players in the twisted world of [b]Little Nightmares[/b], creating an emotional connection with the game that lasts long after the credits roll.

However, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] isn't without its flaws. Some players might find the controls a bit clunky at times, leading to frustrating moments during high-stress situations. Additionally, the game's brevity might leave players wanting more, as the journey can be completed in just a few hours.

In conclusion, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] is a captivating experience that excels in creating an unforgettable and chilling adventure. With its striking art style, atmospheric world, and clever gameplay mechanics, it manages to immerse players in a hauntingly beautiful nightmare. Although a few shortcomings hold it back from perfection, the game's overall experience is undoubtedly worth exploring for fans of atmospheric and puzzle-driven adventures. [b]Little Nightmares[/b] successfully delivers a unique and unforgettable journey into the darkness.

[h1]One word or phrase to sum up the experience[/h1]
[i]Chillingly effective little horror puzzle-adventure-stealth game[/i]

[h1]Performance/Bug related incidents[/h1]
[i]None were experienced during my playtime with the game[/i]

[h1]Similar to games[/h1]
[i][b]Resident Evil 2[/b], [b]Outlast[/b], [b]Amnesia: The Dark Descent[/b][/i]

[h1]A Nightmarish Delight: "Little Nightmares" Review[/h1]

[b]Graphics:[/b] [i]Stunning[/i]. The visuals in "Little Nightmares" are nothing short of breathtaking. From the grotesque adversaries to the intricate details in the environment, it's a feast for the eyes.

[b]Camera Perspectives:[/b] Ever feel like you're being watched? The unique camera angles in this game will have you looking over your shoulder. They add to the immersion and make you feel like you're right there in the thick of it.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Pattern escapes, anxiety-inducing moments, and a concept that's as creepy as it is captivating. This game doesn't just play; it [u]haunts[/u].

[b]Music:[/b] Top notch and extra creepy. The soundtrack adds layers to the wonder of the game, making your skin crawl in the best way possible.

[strike]Cons:[/strike] [spoiler]There are none. Seriously.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

In conclusion, "Little Nightmares" is a must-play. Whether you're a fan of horror or just looking for something different, this game delivers. [b]Highly recommended[/b].

Grab your copy and dive into the nightmare. You won't regret it.

This game is absolutely amazing! Nothing can prepare you for the events that take place around each corner. The game manages to create such an overwhelming feeling of anxiety for the player due to its great sound design and horrifying monsters all wanting to harm you. As the player you are constantly left feeling on edge waiting to see whats about to happen next in the story. My play time includes watching a 2 hour movie and 2 episodes of One Punch man, so yes, the game is rather short. Around 5 to 7 hours is more accurate to portray the time I actually spent ''playing'' the game. I suppose the main reason why I went ahead and went to do something else is that I find one hit mechanics rather frustrating. So as to not ruin the wonderful experience that Little Nightmares has to offer, I just went and did something else for a bit, and came back with a fresh outlook. 

You will die, and instantly at that, to some bosses... or rather encounters. It can be annoying to figure out what it is you need to do, but once you know, it's just a matter of timing it right and moving on becomes easy.

The story is weird, but in a nice way. Kinda like a grim Tim Burton tale. If you don't know Tim Burton shame on you.

Frustrating Controls Hamper an Otherwise Promising Game

Review:

I recently had the opportunity to play Little Nightmares], and while I was initially drawn in by its intriguing concept and impressive visuals, I couldn't help but be disappointed by the inconsistent and clunky controls. I experimented with both keyboard/mouse and controller inputs, and although the latter provided a slightly better experience, I still found myself struggling to execute even the simplest of actions.

One of the most frustrating aspects was the character's inability to consistently grab switches or ledges, despite my repeated attempts to do so. It became an exercise in frustration, spending five minutes on what should have been a straightforward task. While I must acknowledge that the control issues were not constant throughout the game, the inconsistency only added to my annoyance. There were moments when the controls worked flawlessly, but those instances were overshadowed by the times they failed, leaving me exasperated and unable to fully enjoy the gameplay.

As a result of these control frustrations, I ultimately decided to request a refund. It's a shame because the potential of the game was evident, and the visuals were truly impressive. However, the control inconsistencies greatly hindered my overall experience and prevented me from fully immersing myself in the game's world.

Overall, Little Nightmares has the foundation for an engaging and visually appealing experience. However, until the control issues are addressed and improved, it falls short of its potential and becomes a source of frustration rather than enjoyment.

I like the atmosphere but the controls are awful and coupled with the weird 2D/3D perspective it just makes the platforming part a living hell. And it doesn't help that there is no save option only an automatic checkpoint system with checkpoints sometimes being very sparse. So I find myself replaying long chunks of boring sections with a slow-moving character (even sprinting is very leisurely in this game) just because I keep messing up a single hard jump due to clunky controls and/or confusing perspective. The biggest horror in this game is that, not the monsters lurking around in the darkness.

One of the standout features of Little Nightmares is its stunning visuals and exceptional artistic direction. The game presents a beautifully macabre world with its detailed environments, grotesque character designs, and atmospheric lighting. The use of a dim color palette and clever camera angles perfectly amplifies the sense of dread, making every corner feel ominous and foreboding. From the eerie, dilapidated ship to the haunting depths of The Maw, each location is meticulously crafted to evoke a sense of unease, further immersing players in this dark and twisted world.

Little Nightmares is a captivating and atmospheric masterpiece that delivers a truly unforgettable gaming experience. Its stunning visuals, immersive game-play, and thought-provoking narrative come together to create a dark and twisted world that players won't soon forget. Whether you're a fan of puzzle-platforms or simply enjoy games that push the boundaries of storytelling, Little Nightmares is an absolute must-play. Tarsier Studios has truly crafted a hauntingly beautiful nightmare that will leave you both unsettled and awestruck, solidifying its place as a modern classic in the genre.
 
Little Nightmares' sound design deserves special mention for its ability to create an immersive and spine-chilling experience. From the creaking of the ship's hull to the haunting melodies that echo through the halls of The Maw, the audio perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, adding an extra layer of unease and tension. The ambient sounds and subtle hints intensify the feeling of being constantly watched, keeping players on edge and heightening the overall immersion.

[b]Little Nightmares[/b] is a hidden gem in the world of indie horror games. This atmospheric puzzle-platformer will [i]haunt[/i] your dreams and leave you [i]breathless[/i] with its dark and twisted visuals.

The game's art style is [b]stunning[/b], with its unique blend of eerie and beautiful. The attention to detail is [i]impressive[/i], with every corner of the game world meticulously crafted to create a sense of [i]dread[/i] and [i]unease[/i]. The developers have truly captured the essence of a nightmare, and the result is a visually mesmerizing experience.

The gameplay in Little Nightmares is a perfect balance of [i]platforming[/i] and [i]puzzle-solving[/i]. As the protagonist, Six, you must navigate through a series of [i]treacherous[/i] environments and evade the clutches of grotesque and [i]terrifying[/i] enemies. The controls are [b]responsive[/b] and [b]intuitive[/b], allowing for precise movements and [i]tense[/i] encounters. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring you to think outside the box and use your surroundings to progress. Each level presents a new challenge, and the sense of accomplishment upon solving them is immensely satisfying.

Little Nightmares also excels in its [i]sound design[/i]. The haunting soundtrack perfectly complements the dark and atmospheric visuals, adding another layer of immersion to the game. The subtle ambient noises and unsettling sound effects create an [i]unnerving[/i] atmosphere that keeps you on edge throughout your journey. The audio cues also play a crucial role in alerting you to potential dangers, heightening the tension and making for an even more [i]heart-pounding[/i] experience.

One of the standout aspects of Little Nightmares is its ability to tell a [i]compelling[/i] story without relying heavily on dialogue. The narrative is conveyed through environmental storytelling and subtle hints, allowing players to interpret and piece together the dark secrets of the game world. The mystery surrounding Six's journey adds an extra layer of intrigue, making you eager to uncover the truth behind the nightmares.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is a must-play for fans of atmospheric horror games. With its stunning visuals, immersive sound design, and engaging gameplay, it delivers an unforgettable experience that will stay with you long after you've finished playing. Prepare to be [i]captivated[/i] and [i]terrified[/i] by the haunting world of Little Nightmares.

Little Nightmares is a puzzle platformer game that performs very well in the field of puzzle, but in the field of platformer it has some minor problems. One of these problems is the somewhat dry and clumsy controls of the game. Of course, this problem is not very severe, but this problem exist in the game, and this sometimes make a simple jump or hiding under a table a difficult task. This problem gets worse when you know that sometimes there is a long distance between checkpoins in the game and there is no lantern or candle on the way to activate a checkpoint yourself by lightning it. As a result, one wrong jump can cause you to have a travel a long way again.

But in the field of puzzles, we see the same creativity that we saw in a game like Inside, in Little Nightmares. It is true that the number of puzzles in the game is not very much, but the existing ones have an interesting design and are fun to solve.

But the gameplay is not limited to solving puzzles or jumping from another platform to another, and one of the positive features of Little Nightmares compared to other works is the presence of the stealth and chase elements in the game. During the game, we see antagonists who just need to see you to be killed. Their presence in the scene is enough to give you a sense of fear and try to take refuge in a safe corner immediately. As a result, in the game, you must first try not to be seen, and then, if you are seen, you must try to escape from the enemy in chases.

But in my opinion, the main part of Little Nightmares game is its story. After finishing the game, gamers will be divided into two groups. Some people will criticize the game because of not very clear and clear ending and some people who have received a certain concept from the game and its ending and will discuss it and enjoy the story.

Little Nightmares is really at a very good level in terms of graphics, both technically and artistically. The lightning of the game are the main positive future of its graphic aspect, which are at the top throughout the game and give a special beauty to this effect. On the other hand, the environments are usually designed in great detail and this also applies to the characters. It is true the main character of the game has relatively simple design, but the other characters in the game all have rich and detailed designs.

In terms of audio, the game is at a very good level, and the voiceovers are well and accurately performed and play a significant role in inducing a sense of fear in the game.

In general, Little Nightmares is one of the best platformer games that can entertain you with its gameplay and it is so rich in terms of story that gamers can have their own interpretation of it and can analyze and enjoy it as they want.
