Little Nightmares is a hauntingly beautiful and delightfully unsettling journey that plunges you into a world of nightmares straight out of your darkest childhood fears. With its unique visual style, atmospheric sound design, and intuitive gameplay, it's a game that immerses you in a chilling and captivating experience.

From the moment you take control of Six, a small raincoat-clad protagonist, you're transported to a realm where the line between dreams and nightmares blurs. The art direction in Little Nightmares is a true marvel, with its twisted and grotesque environments that evoke a sense of both wonder and dread. The attention to detail in the visual design, from the dilapidated furniture to the grotesque inhabitants, creates a truly immersive and macabre world.

The gameplay mechanics in Little Nightmares strike a perfect balance between exploration, puzzle-solving, and stealth. Each area is a meticulously crafted playground of nightmares, filled with cleverly designed puzzles and lurking dangers. As you navigate through the dimly lit corridors and avoid the clutches of grotesque beings, you can't help but feel a constant sense of tension and unease. The game masterfully builds suspense, making each encounter a heart-pounding and adrenaline-fueled experience.

One of the standout features of Little Nightmares is its ability to tap into your deep-rooted fears and emotions. The narrative unfolds through subtle environmental storytelling, leaving you to piece together the dark and twisted world you find yourself in. It's a game that invites interpretation and introspection, touching on themes of isolation, vulnerability, and the loss of innocence.

The sound design in Little Nightmares deserves special recognition for its contribution to the game's eerie atmosphere. The haunting melodies, ambient noises, and the subtle whispers in the dark all add layers of immersion and further intensify the feeling of dread. Each creaking floorboard, distant wail, and spine-chilling screech resonate in your ears, creating a haunting auditory experience.

Little Nightmares may be a relatively short experience, but it leaves a lasting impression. The combination of its atmospheric visuals, engaging gameplay, and thought-provoking narrative make it a standout in the realm of horror and psychological games. It's a testament to the power of simplicity and the ability of video games to evoke emotions and create a truly immersive experience.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is a captivating dive into the shadows of childhood fears. With its haunting visuals, clever puzzles, and atmospheric sound design, it's a game that stays with you long after you've turned off the console. If you're a fan of atmospheric horror and enjoy thought-provoking experiences that delve into the depths of the human psyche, Little Nightmares is an absolute must-play. Just be prepared to face your fears and uncover the unsettling truths that lie within the darkness.

A charming puzzle-based horror whose atmosphere and soundtrack are its strongest points. The dark fantasy art direction reminds me most of Henry Selic’s works, particularly Coraline, perfectly distilling that uncanny valley of creepy-cute mixed with gothic. Coupled with the dark lullabies and booming orchestral themes it’s easy to become engrossed in the experience. It’s a bit shorter than I’d like it to be, but it mostly serves the game to keep the sections brief and succinct, plus the Secrets of the Maw DLC adds a slight increase of challenge and length that I was itching for at the end of the base game. As with most games the bosses are the best part, each providing a short but tense encounter with some of the monstrous creatures that inhabit the ship you’re on. Besides the way-points being a little too punishing in their spread sometimes, the game was a pleasant experience through and through that serves as a great killer of a free evening.

Little Nightmares is a captivating and thrilling game that exudes a remarkable atmosphere. While one might anticipate the presence of jumpscares throughout the gameplay, the absence of such elements adds to the game's unique allure. Little Nightmares: The game that will make you question your love for cute little creatures. This twisted and hilarious adventure takes you through a nightmarish world filled with creepy dolls, grotesque chefs, and hungry monsters. It's like a messed-up version of Alice in Wonderland on steroids.

You'll navigate through dark and eerie environments, solving puzzles while trying not to get caught by the terrifying residents of this bizarre realm. And let's not forget about the protagonist, a tiny raincoat-wearing child who is surprisingly agile and resourceful in the face of danger. It's like watching a mini ninja survive in a nightmare circus.

The visual design is both haunting and oddly adorable, with its unique art style making even the most grotesque creatures strangely endearing. Just try not to have nightmares about them after you turn off the game.

Little Nightmares doesn't take itself too seriously, sprinkling dark humor throughout the gameplay. From absurd deaths to unexpected slapstick moments, it's a rollercoaster ride of laughter and spine-tingling thrills.

So, if you're looking for a game that will both scare and tickle your funny bone, jump into the twisted world of Little Nightmares. Just remember to keep a nightlight handy when you go to sleep. You know, just in case.

Little Nightmares is a short game that has plenty of fun contained. After waking up in the middle of nowhere, you explore as a tiny character named Six. However, there are plenty of creepy creatures and challenges awaiting you. This game is a lot of fun and I especially love the environment and lighting as well as the music. Each component adds to each other equally as well. There is also plenty of lore to be unpacked, though not everything is 100% certain and a lot is just theories. Each chapter of the game features different types of enemies and I especially loved the stealth sections in Chapter 1 and 2. Although the game is short, it makes up for it by maintaining its fun puzzles and interesting exploration throughout. This game also feels completely unique to anything I've played before and is completely its own thing. I would definitely recommend this game, and while it seems like the price is a bit high for the game time, I think it is definitely still worth it. You can also purchase a bundle with this game, the second one and all of the DLC which I am yet to play.

Little Nightmares, developed by Tarsier Studios and released in 2017, is a chilling and atmospheric puzzle-platformer that takes players on a haunting journey through a twisted and macabre world. This dark fairy tale adventure offers a unique blend of atmospheric visuals, eerie sound design, and immersive gameplay that will keep you captivated from beginning to end.

One of the most striking aspects of Little Nightmares is its visual design. The game presents a nightmarish world filled with grotesque and unsettling imagery, reminiscent of a distorted child's imagination. The attention to detail in the environments and character designs is exceptional, creating a foreboding atmosphere that oozes with a sense of dread. Each area you traverse is filled with twisted puzzles, eerie lighting, and hauntingly beautiful backdrops, making every step a visually captivating experience.

The gameplay in Little Nightmares is centered around stealth and puzzle-solving. As the protagonist, Six, a small and vulnerable child, you must navigate through the treacherous and oppressive environments while avoiding the attention of grotesque and terrifying enemies. The mechanics are intuitive and easy to grasp, with a focus on timing, observation, and quick thinking. The puzzles are cleverly designed and often require you to think outside the box, adding an additional layer of challenge and satisfaction to the gameplay.

The sound design in Little Nightmares is masterfully executed. The ambient noises, creaking floorboards, and distant echoes create a sense of unease, immersing you further into the eerie world. The absence of dialogue enhances the feeling of isolation and vulnerability, as you rely solely on environmental cues and visual storytelling to understand the narrative. The atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the gameplay, heightening the tension and creating a sense of impending danger.

Little Nightmares successfully manages to tell a compelling and thought-provoking story without relying on explicit exposition. The narrative unfolds gradually, leaving room for interpretation and inviting players to piece together the dark mysteries that surround Six and her nightmarish world. The game's emphasis on atmosphere and symbolism allows for a deeper emotional connection, leaving a lasting impact even after the credits roll.

However, one minor drawback of Little Nightmares is its relatively short length. Clocking in at around six to eight hours for the main campaign, some players may find themselves wanting more of this captivating world. Nevertheless, the concise storytelling and focused gameplay ensure that every moment is filled with tension and intrigue, making it a memorable experience despite its brevity.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is a hauntingly beautiful and atmospheric adventure that delivers an exceptional blend of visual design, immersive gameplay, and thought-provoking storytelling. Its ability to create a sense of dread and unease is a testament to its masterful execution. While it may be a relatively short experience, the game's dark and twisted world will leave a lasting impression on those who dare to step into the shadows. If you're a fan of atmospheric and unconventional horror games, Little Nightmares is a must-play that will linger in your mind long after you've turned off the lights.

TLDR: Little nightmares falls short from being a horror game because it refuses to get past the Disney horror movie line, it falls short with it's bland puzzles to be labeled as a puzzle game, falls short on its sneak and chase system to be an infiltration game, the platforming is okay but not the best to excel as a platformer. It suffers from trying to be many things at once without being able to nail a single one of them. 

—————


I think little nightmares biggest failure is it's wishy washy refusal to commit to be an adult game. The environment insinuates something gruesome going on, but it's never very explicit. This would be okay if there would be explicit moments, like when you are grabbed and lose. But the screen always fades to black avoiding any explicit gruesomeness. Which makes this game feel like horror for kids, but bland as an adult. Hey, maybe that's the idea and I'm just not the target audience. 

The puzzles are all very paint by the numbers. They aren't imaginative or use moon logic, but they are all very very bland. You always have to do what you'd expect to do, so there's very little thinking involved in solving them. The result is you never feel any sense of accomplishment after clearing them because of this. Basically the game is very linear while pretending to be something else, so if you identify the path and just push through you'll get there.

There are a couple of easy nail the jump moments that because of the camera angle you can absolutely miss. This feels not difficult, more like bullshit camera angles. 

Also and this could be because I'm playing it on hard, I feel that the amount of chase the enemies give (even after hidding under tables and such) can feel like absolute bullshit. This forces you sometimes to just run through to clear the stage... Which just makes the sneaking around feel pointless in many places. The controllers are very clunky, you can't even shimmy left while climbing railings so you sometimes have to drop, move to the side and climb again.

To sum it up, little nightmares falls short from being a horror game because it refuses to get past the Disney horror movie line, it falls short with it's bland puzzles to be labeled as a puzzle game, falls short on its sneak and chase system to be an infiltration game, the platforming is okay but not the best to excel as a platformer. It suffers from trying to be many things at once without being able to nail a single one of them. 

In the positive side the art direction is great, but not enough to make up for how bland it is. And let's be honest, it's the only reason you bought this.
Great game for a relaxing night in. Love the sound track, added to the experience. Definitely will play the second one.

Little Nightmares' atmosphere and creative direction is practically untouchable, and features a powerful, dark message with enthralling visuals and sound design that make this game one of the most deeply disturbing horror titles I've ever played. It's so consistently tense and atmospheric. The puzzles and platforming are woven perfectly into the environments. And Little Nightmares kept me at the edge of my seat the whole time, without using any typical horror game tropes or cheap jumpscares, and the compelling story relies entirely on its visually told narrative with zero dialogue.

Despite the great atmosphere that Little Nightmares boasts from front to back, it's not mechanically airtight as a 3D platformer, and sometimes suffers from depth perception issues that can end up with the player dying to something unpredictable. This doesn't create any especially frustrating moments (you usually won't make the same mistake twice), but I definitely got pulled out the atmospheric experience a few times by dying to a long fall because I couldn't tell where to walk/jump.

I'd recommend getting the Complete Edition, as the 3-part Secrets of the Maw DLC (other than some performance issues) is on par with the main game with its atmosphere, creative direction and jaw-dropping ending. I don't think I've ever been as horrified with a game as I was with the ending of the DLC - and it ties into the main game in such a creative and unique way! Overall, 8/10.
Easily one of my favorites. From the captivating story to the lovely gameplay, this game is absolutely stunning.

I also had some empathy/sympathy/admiration for the child protagonist in each game as they're innocent and just trying to get through their own challenging journeys but also... because I unintentionally sent them all to their deaths multiple times.. sorry guys

This game has so much going for it. It's got a brilliant art style, a killer atmosphere, and enough tense moments to capture those looking for them. It's a shame, then, that the other half of this game is toddling around with Six at two miles per hour being hungry.

Okay, perhaps not, but this game's pacing is deadlier than a bomb-defusing snail at times, and it does hamper the otherwise stellar atmosphere. All the characters you come face to face with are incredibly grotesque, and all the dank, corrupted locales are suitably uncomfortable. Looking at the body of a man whose own face has fallen down off his skull while he paws around with arms about 4 times longer than should properly be is something that strikes you the first time you see it. Although your comfort with horror will of course depend on your experience with the genre, and nothing here is *actually* very scary, every single element in this game is infused with the macabre.

The lair is dark and empty, the implications for the prisoners are unfortunate, spaces unfold in uncanny ways that no logical space would allow, and all the while you're never truly alone. Always watched, always on edge. The unease is truly palpable; you are a small child and in typical fashion the world is out to get you.

The actual plot, following an imprisoned girl trying to escape from an ominous vessel where the rich gorge themselves, is about as standard as you might expect. Every time you ask a question the game is probably just going to put its hands up and say "Oooh, isn't it mysterious?" All that is expected of you is to ask why and not require any answers. Because there are none. The game's atmosphere still works wonders without it, and it's a suitable backdrop, but the plot won't make you think about Six's backstory late at night; that's for sure.

The remarkable is mostly saved for the scenery, though, for the gameplay is unremarkable in most ways. You can walk, run, jump, climb, mantle obstacles, and pick up and throw objects. You cannot run too long before running out of stamina. Super basic controls, but the game essentially needs to be this way. If the game had more going on, then it would be limited in the scenarios it could drop the player into (not that there are very many of those, either). Greater depth of gameplay introduces nuances and restrictions which have to be accounted for in the design stage of the levels, thus limiting the possibilities for the encounters. The game [i]needs[/i] to have the player only be capable of basic actions so Six can be seamlessly inserted into whatever tense situation. So while the game will get you very acquainted with running away, picking up objects, and pushing rolly things, I can't be mad at the game for this sort of repetition. It is what makes a horror platformer work to begin with, when its spookiness comes from looking at the game's spooky stuff in its twisted art style. Only in getting the game's most arduous achievement did I find the gameplay undercut by stiff movements and poorly timed sequences that didn't quite cut the mustard when you need perfection. Still, for 99% of players, this won't be a visible issue.

What is considerably easier to be mad about are the mind-bogglingly tedious hunger sections. See, Six needs to eat. And she's really hungry, so she needs to eat once every chapter, on increasingly depraved items. But every time it's the same ritual; a growling stomach followed by slowing the game down to an absolute crawl as you must simperingly quiver along the floor to the edible item, occasionally feeling hunger pangs which stop you entirely. Each time this happens is probably 30 seconds, which doesn't sound like a lot but truly breaks the pace of the game whenever it arises. There is no tension nor fear; only waiting. These sorts of cracks become much more visible when you try to get the "Hard to the Core" achievement, which accounts for a little over half of my 20-hour playtime. Every time I died and restarted the game, the hunger pangs were always the portions I dreaded the most. Beyond that, however, I came to appreciate just how truly limited the game really is. By its nature, the danger in this game is illusory. Not that enemies won't gladly kill you if you walk into them, but the game doesn't [b]want[/b] to kill you. It wants to make you feel like you'll be killed. Everything is so precisely scripted that once you get past the malaise, there is no wizard behind the curtain. You need only give the right inputs and walk in the right spots at the right time and you'll have no trouble. So while your first journey through the Maw is perilous, any replays are likely to strip the crusty, peeling paint right off the wall.

On the subject of replaying, you're most likely to notice that the game's bulk fits mostly at the starting end of the game, and this is pretty unavoidable. While the first two levels can easily take 35-40 minutes to clear and scour for collectible dolls and resident cute beings, the third falls to 20-ish, the fourth to 15, and the fifth to only about 10. On the extreme end, getting Hard to the Core requires beating the game in under an hour deathless; I managed it in 45 minutes. This is probably the game's biggest, most banal issue and if you want to equate price with time I'd say Little Nightmares is slightly costly for what's on offer, although I think having such a polished experience is worth it. Of course, if you want to experience this world and have a good time, I don't think the price tag is disgusting.

As an addendum, the three DLC levels are mostly more of the same, although they focus on more creative gameplay mechanics than in the first game and come up with some good variety. They're a worthy addition to the experience by all means. Plus the narrative is a far sight better.

Overall, Little Nightmares is a horror experience which does a suitable job being a horror experience, despite its indie-darling brevity and gameplay missteps. The visual design is really top-notch and the tension is pretty genuine on your first go around, although there's not much there afterwards so long as you're diligent with your collectables. Buy it, play it, have a good time and see if you can manage not to tear your hair out from the hunger.

Just don't spend 11 hours doing a flawless speedrun of the game. That took ages.

Title: Little Nightmares: A Hauntingly Captivating Adventure

Rating: ★★★★☆

Little Nightmares is a chillingly atmospheric and visually stunning puzzle-platformer that manages to captivate players with its unique art style and haunting narrative. Developed by Tarsier Studios, this indie gem takes you on a dark and surreal journey through a mysterious world filled with grotesque creatures and eerie environments.
spirited away on steroids 10/10
Goods
amazing
Fun game
good

Little Nightmares is a horror puzzle platformer that takes you on an eerie and unsettling journey through a hauntingly imaginative world. You play as Six, a small girl who must navigate through a shadowy, mysterious labyrinthine environment, avoiding grotesque monsters and solving puzzles to unlock new areas.

The game's atmosphere is one of its most compelling features. The graphics are fantastic, with the use of lighting and sound creating a sense of unease that lingers throughout. The game's designers have created a unique, stylised world that is equal parts unsettling and fascinating. The monsters you encounter are twisted and creepy, adding to the overall feeling of dread that permeates the game.

Little Nightmares is also an excellent puzzle game. The puzzles are clever and genuinely challenging, but never impossible to solve. The game does an excellent job of gradually introducing new mechanics and challenges as you progress, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting throughout.

The controls are simple and intuitive, making it easy to jump, dodge, and crawl your way through the game's different environments. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock new skills and abilities that allow you to access new areas, adding to the game's overall sense of discovery and exploration.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is a chilling and beautifully designed game that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Its eerie atmosphere, clever puzzles, and unique visual style make for one of the best games. If you enjoy horror, puzzles, or just want to experience something new and different, Little Nightmares is definitely worth checking out.

This is a game to play again and again (and I have).

Replayable not just for all the little extras you can challenge yourself with, not just for the minutae that tell a story in that oblique and yet perpetually intriguing way, it's just fun gameplay.

It's classic horror gameplay but in that contorted fairy tale quality in which you are tiny, but sharp thing, in a wordless world of monsters. You have no offensive capacity, you can only skulk out of reach but mostly just out of sight away from these gruesome antagonists in a lonely world.

The lore alone is fun to explore on the message boards but it is also a terrifying game both for the sense that anything could come out at any moment and because the moments of chase are heart beatingly tense. The game waits for when you feel safe and confident and then lures you to a moment where you recoil in surprise.

The game play is strictly linear; there is no doubling back or getting lost though it may loop de loop on itself. You can't even carry items.

It's a young game but I already feel nostalgic for it.

It's a great game, very atmospheric and the mechanics are quite good, although I do sometimes find that the character doesn't jump or climb when i want them to (and often when it's most crucial as below).

BUT my big annoyance with this game is that it isn't saved after some quite hard sections.  You feel great having finally beaten something that requires coordination and planning... only to die on the very next part and have to do it another six times, only to fail the next part again.  It leads to an incredible level of frustration.

I've restart this game after changing machines and very quickly remember why I gave up in the first place.  But I recommend it nevertheless because some people might be better at this stuff (and at dealing with repeated failure!) than I am.

A short yet intriguing puzzle game.

Completing this game, DLC included, took me about 4 to 5 hours, so yeah its a short game, regardless, the sheer mystery of the world of Little Nightmares is enough to convince people of trying this game, its dark, creepy, and dangerous, which is perfectly delivered by its presentation, from the designs of the creatures, the world, and its OST, all top notch, it really pulls you into it, wanting you to learn more. 

Gameplay wise, its pretty simple, you wander around as you progress through the levels, and you gotta deal with simple puzzles, while avoiding the various creatures, each one working different from the others, like most other puzzle games, its trial and error, and you gotta find out not only how to solve the puzzles, but also how to avoid the monsters, its a fun and tense experience, for those that like "cute horror" the design of the creatures will likely remind you of the style of Tim Burton. 

The game for the most part had no issues, but i did ran into one bug where one of the monsters got stuck, but besides that, the game is well optimized and youll likely play with minimal if any issues at all.

Its a good puzzle game, not particularly hard, but its enjoyable, and like mentioned, this dark world is really appealing.

Rating: 2/5 Stars

Little Nightmares, a platformer that starts off with simple gameplay, quickly devolves into a maddening and uninspired experience. With the introduction of timers, double jumps, and other challenges that lead to constant game overs, this title is far from enjoyable.

Compared to other games in the genre, such as INSIDE, Little Nightmares falls short and is bogged down by typical game developer puzzles that offer little creativity. Instead of providing a captivating and enjoyable experience, the game becomes an exercise in frustration.

It's worth noting that the sequel to Little Nightmares should also be avoided, as it only exacerbates the issues present in the first game. If you're seeking a thrilling and innovative platformer, it's best to look elsewhere and leave Little Nightmares and its sequel on the shelf.

Been one of my favourite horror games for years and i didn't find it any less fun to replay it on pc. The character design is so unique and creepy, i've never seen a horror game done like this before. A beautiful story is created with absolutely no dialogue which is super impressive. Fear is built throughout the game through sound design and atmosphere, a perfect example of a game not needing cheap jump scares to actually scare you. The secrets of the maw DLC is just as good and creates an amazing connection to the base game. I adore this franchise so much and it's really something that the horror genre needed to see.

I bought Little Nightmares on sale, which mostly happened on a whim. I'm very picky when it comes to video games. Little Nightmares is a nice game but it gets more annoying than scary. The controls are sloppy which leads to frustrating deaths. Part of this is because of my incapability to control the character and struggles with camera angles so the experience might be different for those with a controller. I tend to be quite observant but still got stuck because I never happened to look into the right place - so a lot of trial and error gameplay here...

When talking about the good stuff, Little Nightmares is matchless in its uniqueness, like a fresh breeze in the horror genre that truly stands out. The developers clearly thought outside the box and I appreciate that. With many creepy elements and incredibly tense moments, I’d say this is a solid horror experience. Nothing that deprives you of your beauty sleep, but rather something that slowly creeps its way under your skin, especially the ending.

This game might look innocent and monsters cute but don't let it fool you... Despite not being exactly my type of game, I think this is very worth experiencing as I like the idea of being a small child in a world of huge monsters. However, I have to warn you that if you're a keyboard and mouse user like me, you'll rage-quit pretty often. I don't want you to base your purchase decision on my review, but I can recommend this only if you have a controller.

I would like to go on record and say that this game is incredible. The game itself is with its physics and graphics are a tad primitive, but those qualities are hardly noticeable and do not, in any way, diminish the game itself. The overall playtime is short and it isn't very re-playable, but the story-line makes it completely worth it. The overall innocent feel of the game with a horrific and sinister undertone is genius in my mind. Even six years after the game was released, it is one of the best horror games I have played, largely because it can scare a person without all of the cheap blood and gore. I highly recommend it to anyone whom is interested in 5-7 hours of quality horror gaming.

Oh, Little Nightmares, the game that made me never want to eat soup again.

This game is like a twisted version of Alice in Wonderland, where everything is dark, creepy, and filled with hungry monsters. Seriously, if you thought the Jabberwocky was scary, wait until you meet the Janitor.

But let's talk about the real star of the show here: Six, the little raincoat-wearing protagonist who's basically the Katniss Everdeen of the monster world. She's small, she's sneaky, and she's not afraid to jump on a floating bed and grab a sausage.

The graphics in Little Nightmares are hauntingly beautiful, and the sound design is top-notch. I mean, who knew that a creaky floorboard and a ticking clock could be so terrifying?

All in all, Little Nightmares is a must-play for any horror fan. Just be prepared to have nightmares (pun intended) and maybe skip soup for a while. And if you see a little girl in a yellow raincoat, for the love of all that is holy, don't give her any food.

I thought the graphics looked funky and intriguing so I dived in without knowing anything much about this game. What a surprise! Had no idea it was a platform game, but it's way more sophisticated than that. The characters are both charming and creepy and the story is vague and foggy. It comes together at the end, kind of, but does leave you wondering quite what you just played. I googled it on completion it to fill in the creative gaps and all became clear-er. There weren't many prompts to help along the way so you kind of have to learn via trial by error which includes lots and lots of dying, but luckily the auto saves are frequent and sympathetic. This game really has to be played on a controller which did not please me, my preferred method is mouse and keyboard, but I got to grips with it eventually. Trying to play on mouse and keyboard was not responsive enough for this game which runs on absolute precision - and that is the most challenging aspect of the game. Never have I played a game that requires such exacting movements and angles for success, a slight deviation of direction or the loss of a single second during the chase and escape scenes results in continuous repetitive death, and I died a lot, which became funny after a while and lessened the horror of the monster or monsters I was trying to escape. What twisted minds dream up these things I wonder? But I'm glad they do when it results in enjoyable games like this. I was so intrigued, and had such smooth game play throughout, that I went on to purchase the sequel, or is it a prequel? Who knows, I guess I'll find out.I didn't find The Secrets of the Maw DLC until after I had completed the main game. Couldn't play The Deep at all due to an error, big shame this hasn't been fixed, but The Hideaway and The Residence were really good challenges and answered a few of the questions about the mysterious Maw and its inhabitants.

Little Nightmares is an fascinating game and you should definitely buy it. It’s a true master class in quality over quantity and I wish more AAA game publishers would follow this example. The storyline is relatively short but its so intriguing! Through the entirety of the playthrough I was wishing more cut scenes where just around the corner so I could understand more about six and this place she is running around in. However, the game avoids laying out the story for the player through cut scenes and dialogue, so theses things are few and far between. The story is mostly relayed through the environment so if you want to know more, you’ll have to explore the world around you. This brings the beauty of the game out of the darkness and into a flickering light. The intricate detail of the game is mind blowing so I would strongly suggest periodically stopping to soak it all in. I really love the art style. It reminds me of a Doctor Seuss book but with a Lovecraft twist as everything is very creepy yet somehow child like. 

Don’t hesitate to buy the DLC’s either as they are just as good as the main game. By experiencing this new adventure, the player is given more information applicable to the original story. Making subsequential playthroughs of the game very interesting as you realize how the individual efforts of each protagonist affected one another. This is something I really appreciate because if you want to beat this game multiple playthroughs will be required. Some DLC’s lack a good story but not this one. Its very well thought out and comes full circle. 😉 

One final suggestion. If you play through both the main game and the DLC’s but still feel lost in regard to the story, check out The Leaderboard’s YouTube Video  called “107 Little Nightmare Facts You Should Know!”. It pointed out some really interesting things, that made subsequent playthroughs a treat.

The first few levels had me doubting the complexity of the game, until I soon realized how wonderfully masterful, deep, and unsettling it is. I love a good horror game, and this definitely outperformed my expectations by a long shot. Each section of the game presents its own unique challenges/monsters that satisfy that creepy horror craving I get- If you're even considering this game, then you know what I mean. The levels toggle between chase/fight scenes and puzzles, all of which are difficult enough to be interesting without being overwhelmingly frustrating (like with Little Nightmares 2, in my opinion). The atmosphere/environment is gorgeous in its own grotesque way- the morbid curiosity makes me want to inspect every detail of every level. Kudos to the devs here, I loved this game 100000%. If you got this far in my review, just buy it and play. You will not be dissapointed, whatsoever.

*Having played the second game and 100% both, I feel like a bit of a mini-retrospective review comparing LN and LN2*

GAMEPLAY: First off, I don't think either one is objectively better than the other on a technical level, as they both play the same. LN2 has some new mechanics like an AI companion and a "combat system", but they're so non-intrusive that they don't really shake up anything. Platforming, interacting with objects, and really most everything else that you do is still the same, which is fine because these games didn't really need anything new gameplay-wise.

VISUALS: If it were a contest on which one had the bigger environments, LN2 would win by a landslide - a sprawling city with labyrinthine skyscrapers and plenty of nooks and crannies to explore for those intrepid enough to find all there that there is to find. Yet, this new environment also kills one of the biggest aspects of the franchise -the horror/suspense. Most of LN2 is just empty space, and in a game where the player is meant to be in a state of suspense, the setting plays just a big a part as the enemies do. Sometimes, bigger isn't better in terms of a horror game, and it's here where LN got it right, with the closed-in spaces of the Maw that are just big enough to hide from its unsettling horrors, but not so big that you can escape them. 
Speaking of unsettling horrors, I would say that the superior enemy design belongs to LN. Sure, The Teacher being able to stretch her neck to an infinite length was something to behold, but when you compare her design with that of the Janitor or the Twin Chefs and you find she just looks so...mundane, I guess?
 Additionally, I feel the enemy mobs outside of the boss creatures in LN2 are more generic and overabundant - rather than dealing with a single unique foe or 2 unique enemies that are thematic to each chapter as in LN, you run from mobs of at least 10 that share 3 variant designs between them, and you run from these mobs quite a lot so you've about seen everything in the first few chases. Now, a horde of similar looking enemies is not necessarily a bad thing (those mannequin creatures in LN2's chapter 3 were really good in my opinion), but in a horror game franchise that emphasizes stealth and shrouds itself in suspense, I often feel less is more.

STORY: Looking back, my complaints about LN's story came from an anger more directed at its short playtime. In all actuality, It was an intense story that left me and several others intrigued, with speculations and interesting theories that kept us eager for what was next.  With LN2, we got a tightly knit story that answers none of the pressing questions we had from the first game; I mean, LN ends with Six getting the power to suck the soul from another being while being stranded on top of a slaughterhouse run by an evil Geisha lady defeated with magic mirrors- did we really need to go back in time and tell the story of a character who had no real bearing on what would become future events?
 With prequels, a lot of the trouble arises as it can create holes in the ongoing story set up in the original, but it's doubly worse when it spends the entire game plugging those holes at the expense of the larger narrative. In short, LN is able, story-wise, to stand on its own merits, while LN2, albeit a nice little experience in of and unto itself, is of little consequence in the greater story.
 
LN is a one best pieces of suspenseful storytelling in recent gaming history in all aspects, while its sequel, conversely, drops the ball in just about every way. It's a crying shame that things have turned out the way they have for this franchise, but at the very least, we can still enjoy the first game on its own.

[b] Achievements. 2 playthroughs + deathless run [/b] 

[h1] The Game[/h1]
A very dark and atmospheric 3d platformer. Very interesting story and narrative with a lot of interesting interactions that keeps the game solid throughout the whole playthrough.

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
Finishing chapters followed by collectibles and certain objectives. Hardest one is a deathless run but can be savescummed. Can be done in about 10-15 hours depending on skill and how you do the deathless run. Guides available, DLC required.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
A very dark and intriguing platformer. A strong recommendation for completionists but beware of the deathless run (not that simple or a particularly fun achievement).

One of the most unique games I've ever played, having taken up the torch passed by Limbo. All storytelling is masterfully interwoven within the oppressive, labyrinthine world of The Maw, with the playable protagonists enduring odds constantly stacked against the fact that they are a vulnerable, tiny child in an abusive place designed and run by abominable adults. So much care was put into every inch of the level design, and the monstrosities one faces are equipped with some of the most unnerving design and animation ever to blot an experience. You are a mere plaything of unseen forces, unable to shake the sense of being constantly watched by the eyes that glare from the surroundings. The game-play and puzzle mechanics set a consistently satisfying and challenging pace, with well scripted passages of eerie calm beset by sudden stomach-churning chase sequences. I also don't often find DLC that so aptly re-contextualises the main story, and would regard the three additional DLC chapters as being essential pieces of the full experience.

I cannot recommend this game enough. For fans of the aforementioned Limbo and Inside.

Hang on just a moment, I need to get something off my chest first. Ahem... [i]WHAT IN THE DING-DANG-FLIPPITY-DING-DANG HELL WAS THAT?!?[/i] Sorry about that. Now that I've gotten that out of my system, I suppose it's time to dive into [b]Little Nightmares[/b].

[i]Little Nightmares[/i] is essentially a sight-seeing tour with platforming and light puzzle mechanics where you follow a child [i](apparently named Six, but that isn't really important)[/i] as they journey through what I can only describe as a steamboat to Hell filled with grotesque caricatures of humans that eat what I can only assume is children. Or something like that. Instead of any actual explanation of what is really going on throughout this damned vessel, the entirety of narration is done through performative medium, forgoing dialog and instead relying on a gloomy ambiance and an eerie soundtrack to immerse you into the experience. Because that's really what this title is. It's an experience. The sort of experience that lingers for a while and gnaws at the mind. In that regard it is perfect, which is a rare statement, coming from me.

If [i]Little Nightmares[/i] has any pitfall, it would be that, on occasion, the physics engine and and camera angles don't quite get along. This leads to a few frustrating moments where you may have to attempt to solve a puzzle several times before you finally figure out how to successfully proceed. Beyond that, the puzzles aren't terribly difficult, and navigation through the hellbound vessel is rather straightforward. The level design perfectly illustrates what can be climbed, what looks like a traversable platform, and what may or may not be out to consume your flesh and/or drive you to the depths of insanity where you may never escape.

Now, obviously I recommend this title. At about six total hours of gameplay at most, it does a wonderful job of giving you an experience that stays with you long after you've completed it without overburdening you with tedium and repetitive nonsense. I certainly know that I'll be seeing that long-armed monstrosity in my dreams for some time.

[i]Addendum:[/i] I know it's a long shot that this would ever be read by the developers, but to whomever decided to program the controller vibrations to simulate the pitter-patter of the heart of a terrified child, I simultaneously love and despise you. You made the experience all the more visceral and managed to add a layer of depth to the title I never considered possible. [i]Thank you.[/i]

I really want to like this game. And i do.. well, at least i love the idea, the artwork, the general feeling and everything was just as i thought when i bought it. 

The gameplay however is very slow and the controls feel a tiny bit off. They aren't entirely unresponsive, just a little off. Sadly it's so much so, that you feel annoyed while playing and even more annoyed, when you die in some passages due to the narrow paths you sometimes have to take, in order to survive. 
Respawns take easily 5-10 seconds, with the character slowly getting up and back to motion every time. This, as well as the sometimes not so well placed checkpoints make the entire gameplay side of things rather.. tideous.
Many of the "getting chased"-passages are passed by simply running straight to the right, while sometimes you get punished for not catching on to random mechanics straight away. It just doen't feel well rounded.

As much as i wanna love the game, with the base gameplay i just can't and the closer i got to finishing the game, the more i was longing for it to finally be over.

Gameplay 3/10

Do you remember the scary tales that kids tell each other at a summer camp? Severed black hand, coffin on a wheels, the unwashable blood stain, the cursed basement, etc, etc? While this game does not replicate those exactly, it definitely takes all those children horror stories as an inspiration.

This game is all about the atmosphere. The atmosphere of an alien, scary and dangerous world of grown up's from the children perspective. And the devs managed to grasp it perfectly. You can literally feel (or... remember?) how uncomfortable it is. Full marks for that.

On the downside - the game is quite short. There is literally an achievement for finishing it in under an hour, while an average first-time playthrough will take around 2-3 hours max. Same goes for DLC (which for some reason has been split in 3 parts, while it's a single linear story in fact).

In overall i think it's a good game, but a bit overpriced for the amount of playtime it provides. Get it on a sale and don't forget the DLC as well, since it loops the story in a neat way.

A creepy cool little game. Not overly complex puzzles, except for maybe a couple, and some repetitious timing puzzles that can get a little tedious, but overall a pretty fun game. It started out a bit slow and I was not quite sure what the heck to even do so was getting a little frustrated, but once I figured out most of the stuff you see is just there to...well see, and is not needed to complete the game, it started to get a lot more interesting. Basically your goal is to just keep forging ahead from room to room and on to the next area. It might sound boring and repetitive but it's not and while most of the puzzles require you to get from point A to point B, there are often different ways to do that. 

The ambiance of the game is really the best part...along with the graphics which both get better near the later stages. The sound effects are very well done too. Just kicking a bottle laying on the ground sounds very realistic. As you meet characters along the way the background music and sounds change to match the scene. I also liked how the cut scenes, or more accurately the transition sequences, are somewhat interactive so you might be walking to a new area as part of the cut scene if that makes sense. Either way it was a pretty cool design element.

The game is just very well done , maybe not super long but well worth the few bucks it cost for Little Nightmares I & II. Very much looking forward to playing the second game.

Great game! Watched it many times on YouTube and had a blast playing it myself finally. I found the 3rd DLC chapter to be the scariest portion of the game. My only real issue is the inability to access the Tengu and Fox masks on Steam at all, which you can still get for free on Switch/PS4.

That... was SO much fun, and SO CREEPY. Very few games give me the creeps, but I'm serious, this one gave me goosebumps a few times. And another thing that's nice about this particular one in this genre (like Inside, Limbo, etc) is that this one struck a FINE balance between all aspects of the game - some challenges without beat 'beat your head on the wall' hard, decently long without EVER becoming a drag (I actually found I wish it had been much longer), 'secrets' to uncover that don't take sixteen days to find. Not much in the way of 'puzzles'... Just a couple of 'em, and not very hard. But it doesn't detract from the playability and fun. Just all around, this was a PERFECTLY balanced game.

I played it on my Steam Deck, and I'm uncertain if my PC brothers & sisters experienced this, but unfortunately there were a few hard crashes during the play-through while on Steam Deck. It was NOT frequent at all, so I did not find myself hurling the SD out the window in rage, and the checkpoints are fairly frequent, so when it did happen, I didn't find myself losing ninety million hours of progress.

Since this is in the genre of "drop you into the world without much of an explanation"... Since this is the kind of game that tells the story simply through the atmosphere, events, and imagery... it could potentially be spoiling to openly describe some of the stuff. Also, since the element of horror relies on confronting the horrible and unexpected, some might consider my brief descriptions a spoiler. I'm going to blank out some of the following. Note, I won't include any spoilers such as puzzle-solves, important events, etc. but I don't want to spoil this for anyone.

In this world, you are [spoiler] a little kid in a raincoat, with nothing but a Zippo lighter for light - not even a pair of shoes.[/spoiler] You find yourself in [spoiler] an enormous place - I don't want to reveal what it is even in this blanked out part - filled with horrifying, mutated 'adult' figures[/spoiler] who apparently [spoiler]keep children captive for nefarious purposes[/spoiler]. Your goal is to [spoiler]sneak around through the twisted environment, dodging the brain-dead, zombie-like mutant beings who are constantly trying to kill you[/spoiler]. Along the way, you perform small tasks to earn achievements.. some of which are cute, some of which are odd.

I can tell you this game will probably catch you by surprise. There were a few moments in the play-through I was very much NOT expecting. Plenty of fairly predictable things, yes, but... also things that left me thinking, "what!? No... no, surely not."

Again, not a ton of time spent. I'm showing 4.7 hr having beat it.

That said, my usual "should you buy it full price?" is a bit of a toss-up. The game is absolutely FANTASTIC. If it were a little cheaper, I would be driving over to your house to click the "add to cart" button FOR you. But as short as it is... I very much hate to say it, since I enjoyed it so much, but I could see some folks feeling a little disappointed by the length. I still think it's well worth it, but could see how others might not feel that way.

The graphics, the sound, the playability (minus the few crashes) were absolutely incredible, so if you're looking for a game you can truly experience, one with actual moments of dread and horror, THIS ONE IS IT. If it's on sale, SNAG THAT GAME UP SO FAST you don't even think about it.

My all time favorite. I love it for its art, story, gameplay, and beautiful music. To me, nothing gets better than this. Seriously. Buy it now.

So, I did beat the game, but by the end I really wasn't enjoying it. The ambiance and mood are spot on, and the lighting and shadows in particular are impressive. That said, this game plays like crap, has no plot, no story, no attention to detail, no continuity. You never know who or what the protagonist is, the design is cute but doesn't really make sense. By the end, you don't even know why you're playing as them. The monsters aren't scary at all, just hideously ugly. Animations are bad and lazy, I kept expecting something exiting only to see something very easy to animate. When a guy gets his arm cut off by a 4 inch thick door, it just comes off as a cylinder instead of being squished on the end, or anything that would have taken literally any time to model. I felt so much missed opportunity. The AI sees you through walls, then loses you in corners. Save points range from basically save scumming for you, to about a minute away on particularly difficult sections. And by difficult, I usually mean clunky and unfair, like a section where you run down a table with people grabbing at you. I think the intention was that most players would get through in a couple tries because of how loose the tolerance to get through is, but because you can't tell how far they'll be able to reach, the fact that the reaches overlap, the hitboxes are longer than the ends of the fingers, and you literally can't dodge the hands without just getting lucky, it becomes a game of random chance that took me about 20 tries. There's candles you can light, don't know why. There's little goblins with paper cups on their heads that you can pick up and put back down, don't know why. Your character keeps getting hungry, even though the whole game takes place with food everywhere. You literally walk out of a room filled with sausage and carrots and collapse to the floor in starvation. I won't even get into the story, it's not there. You learn nothing. The world is pointless. The creatures are pointless. Literally not a single event in this game comes up at a later point. Stuff just happens, your character does things that don't make sense, then the game ends with no climax, no explanation, and 10 minutes of unskippable credits. It's not a slog for the most part, I did finish it after all. I was able to enjoy the vision of the creators. However, I'm genuinely unsure what the makers of this game wanted me to get out of it.
Overall, this is little more than a polished turd. There is definitely a kind of person who could enjoy this, but if you have a concept of how games are made, then it's easy to tell how lazy and cheap this all is.

Good: the game is absolutely gorgeous.

Bad: the puzzles aren't satisfying, and the movement can be awkward.

Overall, I recommend this game. Really, it's more of a movie - and I recommend playing it as such. If you ever get stuck for more than 2 minutes, just look up how to proceed on YouTube. I did that a few times, and each time, my reaction was, "oh, well that puzzle was stupid." 

Unfortunately, the more frustrating parts of the game involve some moderately precise sequence of movements - usually to just barely escape an enemy's clutching fist. The movement is just a little bit too awkward for these parts to be any fun.

But because it is so visually stunning, I definitely enjoyed myself, and will check out the sequel to see if the gameplay has improved any.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Probably one of the best games I've ever played. This is a masterclass in environmental storytelling, with powerful themes and engaging gameplay. It keeps up tension beautifully despite a lack of jumpscares and only small losses upon death. I would recommend this to anyone, including the three DLC levels. The ending of both the main game and the DLC are powerful, unexpected, and tie the story together. There are no awkward breaks for dialogue, and the puzzles are common sense, but still very satisfying to complete. I could not recommend this game more.

I'll start off by saying I am a huge fan of the Little Nightmares series. It's a truly unique experience.

For those who are new to this series I'll start of by saying the one downside to this game, because it's a quick answer. The game is short. Now that that's said let me say why I recommend this game.

I think this game would be in the liking of almost every gamer. Sure the game is short, but the story that it tells is very much worth it. You start playing the game knowing literally nothing except that you're a small girl in an eerie space. As you play through the game you'll see fractions of the story here and there and you get to puzzle together just where you are and why you are there and why the Little Nightmares' universe is the way it is. There aren't many games out there with this approach and I myself am 100% sure this game takes the lead in the execution.
If you're not much of a story person and just want to play something pretty or scary then don't worry. I think the game does good, nay amazing actually, with its horrors and scares and definitely its visuals and sound design. The artstyle is something I haven't seen in any game out there. Combined with the beautiful sounds and scares it gives shiverings throughout the body. Just wonderful.

in conclusion, sure the game is short (about 6 - 20 hours playtime if you play it in an enjoyable pace) but that doesn't mean it wasn't worth the experience. My experience with Little Nightmares and the sequel as well will stick with me for my whole life as a beautiful gem of a game. After I played the first game I couldn't wait to play the sequal (last game of the series) and tbh I had more fun playing the sequal. 


IF you're interested in only 1 of the 2 Little Nightmare games, you can choose whichever one you play first. The games are connected storywise, and it is fun to play them both, but trust me it doesn't matter which one you play first.

Being totally honest, I do not reccomend it. There are tons of better horror games with that type of graphics etc. The game is just boring, it might have been a hit back when it was released but if you're thinking of buying it now, there are alot of better, newer games.

Little Nightmares is such a true "nightmare fueled" gem of a game. TLDR: Buy on sale, not worth $20, because it's too short. Great game though.

Ok, so this wasn't an easy rating; the game is good, like really good, with super interesting environments and creature design, as well as fun & creepy gameplay. BUT, you're effectively getting 3 hours of gameplay for $20, which, is frankly quite ludicrous. Yes it has DLC's, but those cost extra and they only add an hour onto that run time.

I'm not usually one who complains about game run time, but seriously don't buy this game at full price, buy it on like a $5 sale (DLC included) because it is far too short to justify that pitiful runtime. For reference, a very similarly lengthed cinematic platformer Limbo is half the cost with about a 4 hour runtime.

Runtime aside, this is some of the best horror platforming around, it feels really tense and every monster encounter is extremely fun, which is probably why I'm so bummed how short it is. Sound design is also amazing, and the story is kept purposely vague so that your mind tries to piece together what's going on in this world. The only complaint I have is the ending, (don't worry, won't spoil it) because of how abrupt it is, it really feels like it shoulda had more to it.

Little Nightmares is a thrilling puzzle-platform horror game that only makes you want to play more. The storyline is very well made, with the main character, Six, progressing through various levels themed around different rooms, such as the kitchen or restaurant. The creepy and somewhat disturbing character design is definitely something that made me want to play this game, and it genuinely gave me stress when being chased down by a hungry chef. On top of the fantastic storyline, the collectible system is very well designed, placing gnomes and statues, for example, in areas you wouldn’t think to look in. This adds to the level of exploration in the game. If you like a good horror game to creep you out, Little Nightmares will definitely tick the box.

Like many others, I can't help comparing Little Nightmares to INSIDE, but for me that's not necessarily a good thing.

Like INSIDE, it's a very pretty, atmospheric 2.5D platformer, where you traverse a mysteriously hostile world as a tiny human. A lot of traps await and a lot of things are out to get you, and you have to sneak past them all on the way to freedom (?). The world design is gloomy yet charming and the music adds to the experience.

Like in INSIDE, the journey is at times quite monotonous, with not enough movement mechanics to keep the player engaged physically. Because of the lack of narration and the mysteriousness of everything, it's also difficult to get engaged emotionally, other than "protect this cute little thing from dem ugly big things". The puzzles were decent, but most of the time rather trivial, so intellectual engagement also wasn't really a thing. Because of the overall lack of engagement, I simply didn't care about the game most of the way through, which is a shame, because the concept felt like it had more potential!

Like INISDE, it's a solid 6.

Not the type of game that freaks you out with jump scares like typical horror games. Rather, it takes the time to build up an eerie environment, gives you a feeling of anxiety by using realistic aspects and allows you to view and experience elaborate, detailed and well thought out scenes no matter where you go. Really gets you on the edge of your seat, waiting to see what'll happen next. Takes time to reach the climax of each section, but absolutely worth the wait every time. My favorite horror game to date

This is EXACTLY what horror should be. I was absolutely pleasantly surprised by Little Nightmares! I first saw this game recommended to me maybe a year ago and I thought eh, doesn't seem too great. Well, I was VERY wrong!

Little Nightmares is a puzzle-platform horror game, of course. That says a lot about it already but what surprised me most about this game was the "story". The game itself reminds me heavily of the movie "Coraline", it has very similar vibes, and I think it could be compared to Tim Burton as well. It is that type of horror, no jumpscares at all, nothing trying hard to scare you. You can play this game and not be scared at all, it has much more of a creepy and unsettling feeling, in terms of design and atmosphere. (Which is something that Portal also pulls off extremely well). The game involves stealth- outrunning and avoiding enemies and a lot of hiding, so it definitely gives you adrenaline at some parts. Again, all I could think while playing this was that THIS is what true horror should be! No "trying too hard" to be scary, but just quite subtly having creepy aspects, while not being "overly" scary, if you know what I mean. The creepiness of this game isn't shoved in your face- THAT is what horror needs to be!

I put most emphasis on my love for this game on its story as I mentioned above. It is an extremely unsettling story, not too obviously told, but something you pick up on by inspecting the environment since there is no speech in this game. It is a silent told story, and a very good one. A lot of Little Nightmares is left up to personal interpretation, like "what does that actually mean?", since it's not actually explained and you just watch what happens instead, you can think of some answers yourself. It got me googling all sorts of questions about it and watching lore videos. It's all so creepy, perfectly designed and thought-out, I honestly am in love with it and the amount of questions you have after completion. I just want to know so much more than it tells you!
The art style and design is perfect paired with everything else about it. Honestly, I think the game is a masterpiece. I imagine if I played this as a kid I would've loved it, but it would've also been terrifying!

The achievements are also fun, there are collectable-based achievements(Nomes, lanterns, statues), and some you get from doing small things in the game. And then there's the one where you speed run the game without dying in less than an hour.

It is a short game and can be completed in an hour or two, but I took my time with it and completed it in six hours- so it's all about the personal amount of time you want to spend with it, I think. I didn't want it to be over, it immediately hooked me. I definitely recommend this game. 9/10
Good game. The graphics are really beautiful and I really like the environments in general. Music is great and the atmosphere is just right. It's fun to hunt for the achievements too!

Would I recommend it? Tough question honestly. I will make this short and blunt:

Atmosphere good, rest bad. I respect the game, but I do not like it.

Not even remotely as good as Limbo.

Now for some more explanations: Yes the creepy, horror vibe atmosphere is well done. It even manages to produce some very eerie moments of tension or jump scares and it does that quite effectively. The whole experience is more unsetteling than one may expect and that is good.
I was kinda wondering about the whole "how can you like Six (the protagonist) after playing" meme. That I understand. I even marvel at the balls of this choice, but not giving the player any agency in it felt really shit.
Do not spoil yourself, this is possibly the most shocking twist of the game!
[spoiler]I did not want to eat the gnome aka the kid from the DLC. I literally reloaded the checkpoint cause I thaught that I had aimed poorly past the sausage. This sucks very much.[/spoiler]
I do understand the artistic vision behind it, but it really didnt endear me to the protagonist or make me want to keep playing whatsoever. After havin a sneak peak at some of the stuff from Little Nightmares 2 I have decided that I may as well skip that one. It is such a down beat kind of story, you really need to be up for that and I am not. I would love to overcome some hardship, but not at the cost of my humanity basically.

Now, in terms of gameplay this is quite poor. The puzzles range between obvious to the extreme and completely obscure without much in the middle. Often one knows quickly what needs to be done, but the execution is made difficult by the pathetically bad controls. I did not get used to those during the entire playthrough despite them being very simple. Everything feels wonkly, sticky and overall unresponsive to the degree that it made playing a chore.
Some puzzles will only be solved due to the very limited room that you have to maneuver so eventually you stumble over the completely non obvious way that the puzzles works with stuff behaving in a way that it simply did not behave before or possibilities of interaction that were not possible before.

The pseudo 3D works well for the atmosphere, but makes navigation a pain. Add to this the unwilling camera and you have a recipe for frustration.

Overall the gameplay is very poor. I forced myself through it, because I was curious in terms of the story and where it might lead, but I was certainly not rooting for anyone anymore and detached myself emotionally early on. Lucky me when you consider the ending of the DLC which admittedly is balsy and a fantastic sucker punch. I can respect that, but I do not like it.
the mash of cute, puzzles and horror was a wonderful breath of fresh air. highly recommend it.

I also noticed that because this game has a side view, sometimes having a gauge on how close/far the main character is to the screen may be quite challenging. Other than all that I'd totally recommend this game to any horror fan! Really looking forward to trying out Little Nightmares 2 now! And I can't emphasise enough how the style and concept of this game is just stunning!

This is one of the better games that I have ever played. The story alone is probably top 5 easily. It is full of twists and turns that will keep you thinking, "what terrible creature will I find through this door?," the entire way through. The atmosphere really sets the mood as well, giving off the true horror feel that any good horror game should possess. And lets not forget our main protagonist, six. At first she just seems like a normal kid; a little yellow raincoat hiding a scared child in a strange world beneath it. But as you progress, you quickly realize that six is much more. I won't tell you how much more to keep this spoiler free, but I will say that the devs have done a magnificent job with every aspect of this game: story line, atmosphere, ambiance, and, of course, characters. 

My only complaint is that there just wasn't enough. I love games that leave you craving more, but I finished this game in just under 5 hours. I was speed running a little bit, but it is still just a little short.

However, I do believe the pros vastly outweigh the cons with this game. It is definitely worth buying if you are a true fan of a good plot, or plot twist. ;)

I hate this game. The gameplay mechanics are so obnoxious that it sucks the fun out of the game. I've had this game for over a year and I finished the 3,4hrs story just now, because the gameplay feels so repulsive and I've felt reluctant to continue playing this.
How do the mechanics suck, you ask? Imagine getting the gist of where to go in the game. You try to force your little girl of a character to run/jump/grab/grasp things to get there, only to fail 10 times in a row thanks to the subhuman level of gameplay optimization. As a result you get evermore infuriated and the game keeps throwing you more narrow lines to follow/climb with the same dull controls. So much for the "GrEaT aMbIeNcE".

Also, the puzzles aren't that great, and have counter-intuitive answers to them every now and then.
In the end your character turns into a walking aneurysm, and you can't skip the credits. I skipped them with Ctrl + Alt + Del.

While Little Nightmares sometimes struggles with making its gameplay and puzzles truly enjoyable, the story and world are where it shines bright.

The world is sort of Lovecraft-esque horror, in the sense that it's impossible to be 100% certain what you are seeing or experiencing. It doesn't outright explain anything at all, it's a bit abstract, and that works so well in the game's favor. Not only was I disturbed by the uncanny nature of things, but being uncertain how and why this world's supernatural systems worked made it that much scarier and intimidating. I could see that what that one thing was doing was bad, but I didn't actually know what it was doing, and that's unnerving.

I suppose I say "story" in the loosest sense; it's not a traditional narrative, but rather one about the journey, about the moments. It culminates in a surprisingly powerful and even somewhat emotional ending. I can't say more without hinting at spoilers, but personally this game was worth it and I'm glad we got more of the same from these devs in Little Nightmares II.

[h1]Little Nightmares[/h1]

Our main character, Six, in a yellow raincoat, tries to escape from a ship named Maw, fictionalized with the horrors of our childhood nightmares. Although Little Nightmares resembles Playdead's Limbo and Inside at first glance, with a side-scrolling head adorned with little boy and platform elements, it is thematically different from its cousins..

The carefully designed parts of Little Nightmares, whose tension never decreases, contain different nightmares. Who is not on this ship? For example; A ship janitor with short legs but arms several meters long? Of course. Or a cook who looks grotesque and is always at the meat-cutting or eating ceremony? There is room. An older sister wearing a kimono like from Japanese horror movies? Don't be! The design of every scene we meet with these friends is designed in the quality of a painting where Bob Ross expresses his art: careful and ingenious.

Little Nightmares does not contain any fighting mechanics as we are used to this type of game. When you move from scenes that are designed like a toy house to another, you need to analyze the surroundings well and think about how to get out of the nightmare this time. You always do the indispensable actions of platform games, such as finding movement levers and running platforms, climbing the steps with the help of a box. Of course, your enemies do not collect pears while you are doing these in the nauseating rooms of the Maw ship, such as the room of the cook and his wife, inside the pipes, the garbage dump where the shoes are collected (though the janitor does not collect pear balls with those arms). Taking advantage of the small size of the Six, you should always hide in the shadows and the smallest holes and not appear to the enemies. It's okay to be a fodder to these staff at the slightest mistake.

[b]Are we the Little Nightmare?[/b]

I did not have any difficulties in terms of privacy throughout the game. Once you learn the enemies' routines, it is easy to get past them by staying in the shadows, but the most important thing that makes Little Nightmares unique is the use of the fear factor. Most games and movies try to achieve fear by not showing us what we fear. When we are looking for the key to the locked door with a lantern in a dark corridor, what frightens us is to think about when the enemy will come, shouting at the house boards with his steps. Little Nightmares, on the other hand, always puts the enemy in front of you, turning the factor of fear from when to every moment. In some scenes the main event is outside the camera's angle and you have to move the camera to the edge of the scene using the right-stick to see it. So in a way you are going to the fear you expect. Also, the scripted scenes in the game host perhaps the most terrifying moments I've seen in a side-scrolling / horror game. In these scenes reminiscent of a cat-and-mouse chase, the play's magnificent soundtrack does not do its best to rivet the atmosphere.

I know I haven't talked too much into the story of the game. I do this specifically because Little Nightmares is not a very long game anyway. I was able to see the end of the game over a period of three hours in one sitting. The story goes to very interesting places towards the end. Although my mouth was not open when the story of the game was over, a devilish smile appeared on my face. I'm talking vaguely because I don't want to be too explicit, but if you're playing indie games for their stories, Little Nightmare won't disappoint you.

So I praised the game but why is the score 8? Because although Little Nightmares does very well what it does well, it doesn't have some annoying flaws. Perhaps the most annoying part of the game is the automatic recording system, which sometimes takes very long periods in between. I said I finished the game in 3 hours, I suppose half an hour of that was spent by dying at the end of the episode, falling into the saint of the bad recording system and doing everything over again. Also, since the game takes the recordings before the 15-20 seconds of preparation at the beginning of the stage entries, you have to repeat these non-passed parts in every unsuccessful attempt. Besides that, the platform gameplay isn't that great either. While I didn't have too much trouble, Six sometimes resisted not keeping the item I wanted. Also, pressing two keys simultaneously to climb started to tire my hand holding the gamepad after a while.

Little Nightmares has managed to gather both side-scrolls, horror and mysterious story lovers in the same ship. When the creepy atmosphere riveted with its magnificent visuals and music, a game that would be a candidate for being a classic came out.

[i]Pros[/i]

• The perfect and chilling atmosphere.
• An intriguing and immersive story.
• Oh those visuals! Amazing art design, too.

[i]Cons[/i]

• Some puzzles can cause confusion due to perspective issues.
• Seems a little short? When the game was over, I felt like I was not done with the game.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]

• Little Nightmares is not a game that will shake your world, but it definitely brings a new breath to both side-scrolling platformers and horror games genre.

One of the best atmospheric type of horrors games! The world created here is really intriguing and mysterious making you theorize about it right of the bat. The game is creepy in its own way and proves that you don't need tons of jump scares, gore and every other means that are usually used in such productions. In terms of cons, it feels at some points strongly influenced by INSIDE or LIMBO, which is hard to be ignored, but still, it's trying to create something original and for me, it's even more interesting than its rivals, leaving you at the end puzzled and hungry for more. 
The second thing is its controls. I can't tell why it was wrong but in some parts, especially when someone's chasing you, controlling the main protagonist becomes really frustrating and unintuitive. Finally the game length. Three hours it's really not that much, especially that the game doesn't cost comparatively low to its length although I have to say, it does fell like a finished story not rushed at any point. 
Though it doesn't stop me from feeling that they could lengthen it up at least up to six hours. Having said that it's still, in my opinion, a great position that I can recommend to everyone and those who just like to risk playing something different. (I'm about to play it over again).
