It was an ok experience. I'd probably just watch a playthrough on Youtube, even if it's on sale. 

The visuals were fantastic. The theatrical, no clutter HUD and lighting paired with the art style created some stunning shots and sequences.

The gameplay, however, felt clunky, slow, and  frustrating. Balancing on thin pipes is a pain because the camera doesn't give you a great perspective. Momentum is lost the instant you bump into a corner. That'll kill you in any of the many chase segments. And when you do die, the checkpoints are unfair, and after a few cheap deaths, you'll be tapping your foot as you have to wait for the death animation, the loading screen, and the restart animation to conclude before you're placed two rooms back from where you died. I only completed this game because the whole thing is only about 4-6 hours for an average player. Any more and I'd probably put it back on the shelf. All in all, it never really had a payoff for mastering the clunky mechanics and wasn't fun. 

Also, there only seems to be some shred of a story, and from what I gathered, one story thread sees [spoiler]the player character transform into a ravenous murderer. The hunger sequences are themselves a slog to play through as you walk slower and slower all while periodically doubling over in unbearable pain before finally...eating stuff and continuing on your journey. Now the food selection does become more unpleasant as the game progresses, but the final murder and consumption of a well meaning character seems a bit contrived all things considered. Playing as a ravenous murderer is ok, it's just that the transition from helpless  captive to murderer seemed too abrupt and nonsensical, even if the transition is the manifestation of a traumatized child. You'd think the fact that 2 of the 4 hunger sequences involve creatures intentionally stopping to help you during your darkest hour might preserve some fellowship of survival in this hellish world. There was no "aha moment" or build up. It just happens, and for that reason I wish it were cut or explored in a more meaningful fashion.[/spoiler]
The puzzles are my favorite part. Plus the horror aspect just makes it so much better. I love this game and will continue to play it.

[b]+PROS+[/b][list]

[b]-CONS-[/b][list]
[*]I found this game boring.

What a fun, deep, dark and tormented adventure this game is. Technically this is Little Nightmares 2 - but it was released first and the not 100% smooth controls/actions show it. The puzzles are fun, the concept is neat, and the bosses more creepy then anything else. 
Pros: Enjoyable, short but sweet. Achievement humour is everything for me apparently- Throw food in the chefs cauldron and don't forget to play the piano while you're running for your life :)
Cons (Every game has them): I recently played the smoother, more anxiety filled, and over all much creepier second game. They ironed out some kinks I didn't know were there until I replayed the first one afterwards to have the "full story feel". Sometimes the bad guys get stuck and you have to die to un-stick them. You have to carry the keys, which slows you down ever so slightly. The Final Boss is weak. 
Time to get the last achievement - the whole game, 1 hour, no deaths.

I'll start this review with the experience that you'll be having when playing this game. This is a spoiler free section and after this I'll critique the game meaning it'll include spoilers.

I never found this game scary, I found it more to be an amazing, grand, narrative adventure. You play as this tiny character while running from giant monsters. For size comparison, imagine you were the size of a rat roaming around a human house. The times when there were jumpscares it was more of just a half assed "boo". The monsters themselves have an interesting design but all they do is just waddle towards you which are the "chase" scenes. I feel this game should have the monsters thrashing the area to get you as that would make them more menacing and scary, but instead we get an eerie looking monster waddling towards you for 5 seconds and then their dumb AI making them waddle away when you simply go under a desk that they watched you go under. If monsters could interact with objects then escaping them would be heart pounding, but when you realize that you can simply exploit their AI by hiding under something that they WATCHED you go into then that completely breaks immersion. The monsters will just look around like a dumbass and be like "oh well he vanished" and then just go about their day not caring. Overall going through the game is indeed fun but I feel they could have been a little more creative with how you would interact with the environment. This game is worth playing for the great narrative grandness. If you're wanting to play an actual horror game then go play Im Scared.

Now for an actual critique of the game. Furthering my point of the game not being scary, when I arrived at part 4 of the game, my first thought was "mm yes, f a t people". This part of the game is the best especially when escaping the grubby hands of f a t people, however there's a chase scene where you can easily run out of energy and end up dying multiple times, having to restart the chase just because your character has a dumb energy mechanic. You'll only run out of energy about 2, possibly 3 times in the whole game so there really was not a reason to make an energy/stamina mechanic. I heavily disliked the parts where your character would eat as the whole screen would blast music while flickering the lights, this greatly ruins the important parts where the character eats one of those little kkk members and eats the final boss. Like dude, you want to ruin an important moment? then great job cuz the creator is clearly an idiot that doesn't know how to make an impactful scene without ruining it. These scenes shouldn't have music or flickering lights, it should just be plain quiet while having a clear visual (meaning no flickering lights) so that the player can focus on what is currently happening without being distracted or annoyed by the unnecessarily added effects. The visual is greatly reduced when your character eats the lady(final boss), the screen is practically pitch black which was a really stupid idea.

Overall, good game, but not S tier, I'd say C tier. I'm not replaying this game for a while since it's not very interactive. It had a lot of interactive potential but they didn't fully explore creative ways in making the gameplay amazing, it's more of just the same repeated interactions such as going in an elevator, moving through a tight space, and unlocking a door.

The indie game Little Nightmares released in 2017 was a new slot into the horror genre, it take the elements of many previous horror games and pushes it all together to make a truly eerie game. 

I have little to no complaints about little nightmares I think it adapts the dark tone very well keeping the jump scares to a minimum. No game should ever have to rely on jump scares to be a truly good horror game. This game uses chase scenes and disturbing visuals to keep you on the edge of your seat. Me being a panzy myself I was very tense the whole time playing the game I would really struggle to understand a couple of the puzzles but for the most part without any hints it comes naturally. Not being very long is a savior for the game if it was any longer I think the game would be a lot less entertaining. Whole hardetly believe this is one of the best horror games out there and there is no reason why you shouldn't check it out great play through would recomend to all those horror fans out there.

Little Nightmares is a very stylistic gem. It is incredibly similar to LIMBO and INSIDE in terms of story telling and gameplay. However, Little Nightmares features a 3D space with a doll-house view, rather than the locked off 2D play that the other two offer. There is no tutorial or spelled out story, but that started the immersion immediately for me. The story pieced together is very eerie and builds slowly with each level.

However, I did find issue with some of the tracking of movement/grabbing not being consistent. The enemies immediately knowing where the player is upon the smallest hint or even sometimes with no reason at all, is also incredibly frustrating. Some portions took me well over 10 tries, while most of the game was relatively straight forward because of this.

I would still recommend Little Nightmares even with those issues in mind. It was a fun game to explore and unravel. I am excited to play the sequel.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

Little Nightmares has some marvelous environmental designs, effectively grotesque characters patrolling its world, and a mastery of things like tonal lighting that make even screenshots of it both gorgeous and haunting. Such an effective atmosphere compels you to explore deeper into The Maw, but it seems to thrive on its looks alone. The world does tell a story but the clues either are too isolated to extract much from or leave little to the imagination despite some potential metaphorical implications. Puzzles are often weakened by the fact you simply aren’t given many ways to get the puzzle wrong and the danger of the monstrous beings you must run from is lessened by forgiving checkpoints, obvious ways to avoid them, and some artificial feeling limitations to give them a sporting chance. While the DLC improves on some of those elements, Little Nightmares on the whole needs to be thought of as a lightly interactive virtual horror space or else you risk disappointment when the meticulously constructed setting presents its rudimentary gameplay.

5 Stars -  Came in with no background knowledge and was blown away by its masterful story telling. From the graphics to the sound design this game just clicks with the attention to detail and subtlety of every frame being standouts. 
If you're thinking of buying a problem solving game and can withstand some horror elements this is for you, is absolutely well worth the purchase and I highly recommend the companion pieces (the three DLC's as they're continuation of the main story is shockingly brilliant).

Think "Spirited Away" directed by "Tim Burton." Kept me on the edge of my seat. Couple of plot twists. The DLC is a great extension to the story, but not really required to understand the "lore" of the game. I use quotes, because the lore is what you make of it. I love the type of world building that leaves enough mystery for the player to decide. Highly recommend if you love indie games with a rich story telling device through challenging gameplay.

[u] The Main Game: [/u] I absolutely loved this little game. I would describe this game as a horror in the sense of lots of tension, not knowing what could happen next, but not the type of horror which has tons of crazy jump scares - which I'm glad about. The main game is really good to play through, however I felt there were sometimes quite long gaps between checkpoints. The graphics are really good and the story line is great! 
[u] The DLC: [/u] Absolutely loved it and the connections to the main game's story, however I would say that areas of this are much harder than the main game. The biggest thing I like about this, is that there are [b] much more [/b] check points so you don't have to go back as far if something happens. [spoiler] Granny is quite difficult to get through at times so might take a few attempts once you get used to her movements... But the Shadow Kids... Oh my goodness are they difficult! Especially with the PC keys, it's incredibly difficult to point the torch at the correct angles, especially in the areas where the creatures are infinite. It's doable, but will likely take a good few attempts! [/spoiler] If you have an Xbox or PlayStation controller, I'd recommend using that even just for certain, more difficult areas.
[u] Overall: [/u] Great game to play, I'd recommend it if you like horror, as well as a good story. Some areas are very difficult (mainly the DLC), but definitely doable. I'd recommend the DLC, even just for the story connections and extra game play. I'm definitely going to play Little Nightmare 2... Once I've had a break from the intensity of this game!

Every now and then, there comes a game the reminds you that video games are not just dumb fun-- they are an experience. Little Nightmares is an example of how a game can ascend its own gameplay and create a remarkable experience for the player through almost nothing but impeccable world-building, sequencing, and character creation. I have played this game for only 8 hours several months ago, and I still think about it sometimes. I wish more games like this existed.

This is a game that perfectly bottles the point of view of a child in an adults world. In a world triple your size you must play a deadly game of hide and seek while trying to escape from terrifying monsters. The visuals alone are the purest form of nightmare fuel, but with the haunting audio visuals, the feeling of dread and doom expands even further. With every chapter you can tell the creators poured their heart and soul into this project and the payoff is obvious with each passing obstacle. Only shortcoming in this game was the choice of quality over quantity. The game never becomes sterile and the story line stays consistent, just wish there were more levels to this amazing game, but the final product is not something I would part with. Overall, this is a game you won't regret purchasing.

Thematically and artistically I thought this was a cool game. I liked the enemies and their themed settings. Once I figured out how to make the various collectibles count to my total, that part of the game was fun. I've heard the lore is good and I'm interested to learn more about it after finishing the game. 

That said, movement felt very clunky and slow, camera angles were often bad, and the platforming was tedious. Tons of trial and error were necessary in order to figure out how to survive certain sections. The first chapter of the game is also by far the worst, so it makes a bad first impression. It just dragged on and on. It doesn't surprise me that so few people have completed this game, as is clear from global achievement progress.

Given how short and cheap it is, it's probably worth a shot! The memorable moments were enough to make it worth it for me, even though parts were quite a slog.

This game, and its DLC, is a tedious slog through an uninteresting world. The visuals are, at times, striking and the story original but I just couldn't engage. I love these kind of games but this one just fell flat for me.

It's Spirited Away meets Hellraiser. You're a girl trapped in a German Expressionist nightmare, and must use your wits to evade some of the most terrifying monsters I've ever encountered. 

There's no dialogue, giving everything a sense of "WTF is that?!?" The music and sound effects do the talking, each note and inaudible whisper building a sense of dread. The mood is enhanced by possibly the best lighting I've ever seen in a video game. (Which also brilliantly clues you as to how puzzles are solved.) I couldn't put it down, and it got under my skin long after the credits rolled. 

Highly recommend the bundle, as the sequel and DLC are equally mind-blowing..
This game was one of my first ever horror games. It still stands to day as one of my all time favorites. It is incredibly immersive and terrifying. I hope to find more content like it in the future!

you may barely squeeze an hour out of this game.

- The good: atmosphere, graphics, environment & sound
- The bad: movement, vague puzzles, and long respawn times (largely due to unnecessary enemy animations after catching you)

This is one of the few games I think would be more enjoyable to watch a playthrough for rather than play it yourself. The puzzles and level navigation can be quite ambiguous, meaning you end up playing the same little section multiple times to figure out how to get through it. Crucially, this shatters the immersion which is so key to enjoying the best part of the game: its spooky atmosphere. This is something games like Limbo and Inside do very well (balancing atmosphere/challenge/immersion) however this game falls well short.

2/5

It's like Limbo/Inside if you've played those.  It's not so long that it starts to get tiring/repetitive.  The puzzles aren't generally difficult.  I would say Inside had better animations and was the better game, so if you're only going to play one of these kinds of games I would recommend you play Inside, but this is different enough (in terms of its art and world) to be worth your time if you're ok with playing more than one of these types of games.  Basically the gameplay is very easy and is just an excuse to look at the art/animations and take in the world.  If you've never seen the movie Mad God, I highly recommend watching it, because I think Inside in particular draws a lot of inspiration from it, and this game feels like it does too.  But Mad God is a lot darker than these games.
not bad
very cool , very short ,and very creepy

I want to preface this by saying that I'd usually avoid horror games completely, but I watched some videos discussing the lore etc. of this game and it looked so interesting that I decided to give it a try.

And I'm really glad I did. It's such an atmospheric game with a beautiful artstyle that really makes you feel like you're part of the world. I had so much fun looking at everything, and mulling over what each boss might represent. There aren't really any jump-scare moments (i.e. things suddenly leaping out at you), but instead it's more of a constant background dread as you sneak around, with faster-paced sections where you're being chased (these got my heart pumping so fast!)

I died so many times, but by the time I'd finished I felt so much satisfaction in having held my nerve that long. So, to anyone else who's intrigued by the concept but wondering if it's too scary for them...I say take the plunge! I really enjoyed it, and you might too. Now to try the DLCs and the second game!

Little Nightmares is a very unique concept with interesting story telling combined with elements of stealth, exploration and platforming. The most powerful aspect of the game for me was the atmosphere, that feels creepy and scary. This is mostly due to the characters and the level design, but the overall mystery of the story enhances it even further. There are some elements, which I did not particularly like, for example chasing some characters, that just feels like a distraction from the main story. Graphics are good and levels are well designed with a lot of detail. I played the game months ago, and I mostly remember the "bosses", that are very well created and extremely creepy. If you are looking for a game with a scary unique atmosphere I definitely recommend.
I love it, i'll continue to play through the whole game!

It's a great game for dipping your toe in the water of horror as it doesn't contain extreme gore or jump scares. This isn't to say that blood and very minor gore as well as startling scenes and sounds don't exist but they are very minor at that. I also personally find it genius how they instill the feeling that you are a stranger in a place you are not welcome. Honestly I would highly recommend it for anyone who wants to strengthen their horror resistance while also basking in the off-putting nature of the game while navigating through stealth and platforming sections as well as puzzles. There's really so much that this game has to offer that you need to experience first hand.

I really love this game. It’s amazing even if it’s pretty short compared to the other games I’ve played. It’s why I broke it up into parts to make it last longer. It wasn’t scary per say but I was waiting with bated breath at each encounter with the creatures on the Maw. There was no explanation on where Six came from but it was pretty cool to play as her and figure out the puzzles to go through and get out. The creatures were also disgusting and deformed which made them creepy and the noises they made when they saw me combined with the tone of the music changing depending on where I was at. That was also what made it nerve wracking because there really wasn’t music, it was all silent except for background music. Gave me chills. But that was just the main game, I also played the DLCs and I have to say that I enjoyed them a little more than the main game. I could swim and have the nomes help me and I learned a bit more about the main game like where the nomes came from and about the Lady. Overall, I enjoyed it.

I love the atmosphere of Little Nightmares. It's a great gritty tale with excellent pacing and indirect storytelling. However, there are a few sections that are either overly difficult or without any clear solution. After spending half an hour wandering around a room full of mannequins and broken mirrors trying to find an exit I decided to call it quits.

Such strong atmosphere, I loved getting lost in the mind of this small creature as it found its way in this massive world. The whole story remains mysterious even to the end, and I often found myself emotionally lost with the character. I must say I don't understand everything there is to this, but I think that's part of what makes it such a great story. 

Spoilers below:

As a game developer, I hope that my review is somewhat objective. This review contains spoilers about the game.

First of all, the good side of the game is obviously the visual stuff: art style, models, lighting, animations (also little details like wall touching, jump landings, etc.), and world setting (environment, monsters, etc.). However, on visual stuff, the good part ends. Everything else comes with a load of frustration.

An interactive/non-interactive environment is indistinguishable. The most annoying part was on the level where you must walk through a dining table where "guests" are actively eating, avoiding being grabbed and killed. The level is known to be one of the game's hardest parts because it leaves no room for error while it requires precise movement and timings. I will not complain about the difficulty of this part: many others already did it for me. I noticed a sausage handing from the other part of the table, and it was interactable. If you would climb up on the sausage, you can effectively skip the whole dining table and save yourself some time and not suffer from hardcore platforming. At first look, I thought: "brilliant! a hidden shortcut an attentive player could be rewarded with", later I proved myself wrong. However, you cannot climb it, even though previously you used to do it. Alright, whatever, at least you can swing on it, and there is a chair you can jump on and climb. However, when you perform the action and manage to jump on the chair from the sausages - you cannot fully climb on it (even though it is a similar chair you use to climb on the table on the other side).
I am not sure whether the level designer was evil or stupid, but we got what we got - frustration from a broken promise. At this point of the game, I was already mildly infuriated enough to just pass it. Still, I can imagine how terrible the experience would be for a person who would try to use the sausages to climb on the table no matter what and, after a long time, realize - it was just an interactable level decoration.

The second annoying part was the controls: the game requires precision and timing to move forward; however, the controls are clunky: unresponsive, and unpredictable. So it's just player torturing. Unless developers wanted it, which I am not sure is a part of a horror game, but whatever.
I actually felt a sense of the unknown and that feeling of childish fear at the beginning of the game. However, the more I played (especially moved, jumped, etc.), the more annoying, frustrating, and just busy work the game became - completely ruining the initial vibe. I think it is OK to die by mistake. Still, it is unreasonable to punish when you know what to do and fail to do it because of one millimeter in the wrong direction. I can talk about other nasty stuff, but the game already consumed more time than it was worth.

Besides bad implementation, there are some annoying bugs, like random mouse appearance, which throws you to the desktop if you click on something; teleportation during movement (which killed me once when I was passing the "guest dining table" - that was just a top cherry of my experience).

In summary, the game looks good but plays badly. I recommend watching the playthrough on Youtube. It would be a much better experience than actually playing it yourself; additionally, you save your money on it.

Little Nightmares is an adventure horror game, packed with anxiety fueled moments of terror, and a chilling atmosphere that does not let up. The perfect blend of morbid artwork, creepy characters, and unreal graphics make for a truly awesome experience. Waking up as Six, the raincoat wearing protagonist, players must escape the macabre landscape and outsmart, or outmaneuver, some of the most nightmarish bosses you can imagine. The base game is short but memorable, and the DLC adds more content and another character with their own story. Overall, this one is definitely worth the sales price and I would recommend playing with the lights on, Sweet Dreams.

tl;dr Despite the possibly large price tag, Little Nightmares offers a unique and adrenaline-fueling experience, making great use of both its genres.

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
I was recommended Little Nightmares by a friend, and the gameplay and visuals presented were certainly intriguing for me. Having played through the main game multiple times, I am quite certain my expectations have been well satisfied, haha.

Gameplay:
Little Nightmares is a horror/platformer and excels at fulfilling both of these genres. On the platformer side, the contrast of being a small child in a place full of giant objects allows for some fantastic platforming puzzles. Can’t find a way up? Try climbing an impromptu ladder of filing cabinet shelves or cage bars. If you need to hide, try looking around for holes in the floor, or gaps below the furniture. It all feels rather mystical and satisfying. Also, being able to fling around bottles and other random objects you find is really fun, and it helps that the physics work really well here. For the horror side, Little Nightmares works its players by pushing you to do more daring and risky actions in order to continue, often throwing you right in the sights of the monsters you are trying to avoid. This works well because it's no longer just the unnerving aspects of the monsters and environments that contribute to the horror theme, you now have to be the instigator! For example, you can easily sneak past the Janitor (the long-armed guy) to the next room…but then you need to pull a noisy crank to continue, forcing you to give away your location. My explanations cannot do it justice. There were plenty of moments where I realized what I needed to do to progress and I just thought “you are KIDDING me…”
To warn you, the levels seem to be designed to punish the uncareful. Players who run headfirst into challenges will get themselves killed more often than not, while those who take a second to assess their surroundings are rewarded at least with a possible solution for progression. Watch out for the electrified door!
I had some concerns initially about Little Nightmare’s platforming challenges due to the forced camera angle, but the game is surprisingly polished with its controls and I rarely had any frustration with controlling my character. There were a couple annoyances where I tried to slide under some cover quickly, but I missed because I couldn’t tell the depth very well and I slid into a wall instead. Such complaints are mostly minor, though.

Story:
From the game description and intro, all you’re given is that you’re playing as a little girl named Six, trying to escape from this weird vessel. A brief cutscene at the beginning (the only real cutscene in the game) shows a mysterious woman surrounded by fog – the main antagonist. And then you’re thrown into the mess! There’s not a single bit of exposition to be found in Little Nightmares, but its environment does a great job at telling a story on its own. You’ll see disturbing recurring themes such as the seeming child factory that’s running on the island, and the general dilapidated appearance of the vessel itself. The stark size contrast really emphasizes the nightmare part of the game, really making you feel the childhood dread of things like the dark, strange giants, and losing your grip. It’s a thrill ride to the very end, to which I might add that Little Nightmares has one of the most memorable endings I’ve ever seen in a game.

Music:
There’s not really any consistent soundtrack in the game; rather, you get the general ambience of the vessel, plus occasional themes which play based on the current events. These still really strengthen the moods of the game, making everything feel more ominous and unfriendly.

Visuals:
The dark and off-putting style of Little Nightmares really helps to make it feel like the nightmare it wants you to imagine, with even recognizable things being disturbing enough to unsettle you. The physics in the game seem pretty consistent, and Six moves and interacts with objects with believable motion. Most of the monsters you encounter are designed to leave an impression, much like an actual nightmare. There’s a couple hiccups where a monster might move through a solid object, but overall the game is pretty polished.

Replay Value:
Despite being short (with the main game being possible to complete in under an hour), Little Nightmares offers such a great experience that’s easily worth revisiting, and the various hidden collectibles offer even more incentive to do so. Even if the game is rather linear, the monster AI is erratic enough to keep you on your toes even if you know what you are doing. The usual $20-$30 dollars can be a bit much, but purchasing this game on sale is a no-brainer.

In conclusion, players who are looking for a unnerving horror experience will enjoy the challenges offered by Little Nightmares, and those who are into platformers could easily find excitement here as well. For anyone else, the short length combined with the puzzling platformer challenges still offers a great experience, if you don’t mind getting scared.


EDIT FOR DLC REVIEW:
The DLC chapters for Little Nightmares are alright and offer more unique gameplay and puzzles, but they are noticeably less refined compared to the base game. Your objectives are sometimes unclear and frustrating, and there's some places in the chapters where you can get stuck unexpectedly in the terrain. They aren't unplayable, but I would recommend buying them only if you really want to extend the base game

I've known about this game for a while but I finally got around to playing it after a friend recommended it. I'm glad I finally did. This game does horror right. There really aren't many jumpscares, and the few that are here are well placed and don't feel cheap.
This game is all about the atmosphere, it is TENSE! The world is strange and nonsensical, and the enemies are horrifying. But the nomes and protagonist are adorable. It's a very good blend of creepy and cute that is very difficult to pull off, but it's done excellently here.
The puzzles are fun, they story is very vague but fun to figure out. My only issue is that the controls are a bit clunky, and I personally had a hard time with the depth perception, that's especially an issue for the platforming. But I still cleared the game 100% so not too big of a problem in the end. Also it is a bit short, it ended way too soon. But this is still a 100% recommend for sure.

Just played the main game and all three chapters of the DLC over the past couple of days. Some of it is almost ridiculously difficult, either with the platforming, enemy evasion, or the puzzle solving, but don't cheat yourself out of the experience. It is very satisfying. No dialog. No quest markers. No quests! Nothing to read apart from very occasional game mechanic hints. You're like a rat scurrying through a maze with no idea what's around the next corner or through the next doorway. The music, sound effects, visual design, and point of view are chilling and stunning. Spooky, creepy, infuriating, and marvellous. I love it.

I can see it's a good game. The atmosphere's well built, there's almost no jumpscare, and the setting's very much plausible. However I couldn't really get myself to enjoy it. It's really easy to get bored considering how loose the guidance is, how easy it is to die, and how far the checkpoint is from wherever you died. 
In my perspective, changing only one of those aspects could make the game much more enjoyable and immersive. But for what it is now, the horror is very much won over by the frustration from dying over and over failing to find the right path. I haven't finished the game yet (apparently), but for me it's hard to recommend buying this game.

I don't know how to describe this game other than it being capable of causing a lot of feelings - and that I wish I had heard of it sooner! Anyway, some people could dismiss it as yet another "kid running in the dark and getting killed" kind of game, like Limbo, but there's a lot more to it. Graphics are gorgeous, the lighting is beautiful, but I wish it had been updated to support HDR and/or raytracing. The puzzles are good and layered, and satisfying when solved. Another plus side is that it's a short game. So if you're looking for a cheap game you won't have to put in dozens of hours... try Little Nightmares.

Little Nightmares is clearly an art piece, it is gorgeous. I am a firm believer that video games are a form of art, and Little Nightmares demonstrates it beautifully. Every part of the presentation is brilliant, the level, character, art and sound design are all perfect. Playing through this game is a truly wonderful experience, I highly recommend it.
The thing that sticks out to me the most is the character design. The player character is cute, but helps you feel fear of the world around you. Without shoes, it immediately signals that they are unprepared, and its small size makes the terrors of the world seem so much greater. This level of detail is present in every character, with no wasted space or meaningless design. Every part makes you feel uncomfortable when it should and cute when it needs to be. The Chefs are perhaps my favorite, and they feel truly disgusting and horrifying without being gorey or gross.
This game is brilliant, there is no wasted detail. Everything is placed with purpose to make the mundane, a terrifying experience. This is not really a horror game, there are no sorts of tropes that usually drive horror games. Instead it just is a brilliant piece of art, that uses perfect design to make an experience that unsettles and unerves.

I couldn’t get rid of a thought that I’ve seen it all already, multiple times. Its style, atmosphere, clumsy gameplay. Its black pixels that you need to find on a black wall to advance. Its uncontrollable protagonists in the world of dangerous precision. Or was it the intention?

Sometimes if you’d like to covey a story, you better write a book, or make a vid, or choose another medium that wouldn’t be so painfully interactive.

A short game (you'll definitely beat it within 8 hours or less), but worth it.   Doubly so if you managed to grab the DLC, which will help double your playtime with a few new areas to traverse.

Personally, I didn't find it frightening - rather, it was the well-crafted atmosphere and sound design that intrigued me.

Oh, and try not to spoil yourself regarding the plot, it's best to experience the game going in blind.  There's only a couple of troublesome areas - mostly in the kitchen section and the "Tall bedroom" that might require a guide.  Beyond that, it's rather fair and intuitive with it's puzzle design.

I love love LOVE this game. Manages to be scary and memorable without relying on constant jumpscares. It's not super long, but it's just as much fun to replay, and there's little secrets hidden all over the place, so poking around can be quite rewarding! Additionally, I recommend getting it with the DLC included, as the bonus levels almost double the amount of content to play through and they're quite a fun challenge. Even if you're not big on horror, this is a really fun and unique puzzle-platformer that's definitely worth trying out. Stay spooky, friends!

Little Nightmares is relatively short - just five or six hours, if you're lucky. Throughout the game, I never felt like my challenges were repetitive, and I never felt like I was just playing through the same puzzles over and over. My repetition came when I actually had to learn how to succeed at those challenges.
 
It's a game where you're going to fail a lot. The auto-saving checkpoint system is in place, but it is not perfect. More than once, I groaned to find myself set back too far and stuck having to overcome obstacles I had thought I had already overcome. When checkpoints were friendlier, load times had me grumbling in frustration. The ten seconds added up to a lot of waiting time between failures, especially in the more difficult challenges at the end of each chapter.

I think the well-designed game, from the animation to the sound to the presentation and the puzzles, is what makes this game a horror game. 8.5/10.

Such a good game, you're missing out if you haven't tried it. Even if you don't like horror or thriller games, this one is simple enough to go through and doesn't create massive panic or make your heart race too much - just enough.  :3

Perfect amount of spooky characters along with the cutesy (but sinister) look of Six. 
There are still a few bugs and you might clip to the walls sometimes, or get caught through a wall by an enemy while hiding, but all the mechanics make sense, and it's really enjoyable to play. Many times I just took a breather to appreciate the story or graphics of the environment.

I'm not exactly a good "gamer", I've always gotten lucky or learned fast enough to catch on, but that doesn't make me good, and even in this I messed up a bunch of times. It makes you look for different angles to find new solutions to tiny puzzles and it's a great eye-opener.

If you do decide to play it; find and hug all the gnomes, it's worth it in the end :)

I get frustrated with the sluggish controls on occasion, but the gameplay/story combination keeps me coming back. The game is mostly sneaking with mild puzzles and occasional tense/racing moments. I haven't played anything like it, though that doesn't mean there isn't a fair comparison.

The good: 

The graphics are nice. The level design is pretty cool too and the story is dark and interesting.

The bad:

You can only save so often and that coupled with the precise timing required with the not-so-great controls and camera perspectives make for a frustrating experience. I had to look at a YouTube walk through at one point because after jumping to my death like 20 times because I couldn't figure out where I should jump from because of bad perspectives. I knew where I had to jump but kept missing. Where I thought I should be jumping was way off it turns out.

Falling a bunch of times because you can't see exactly where you need too jump, having to start all over again and then wasting minutes just to get back to where you died just isn't fun for me after a few times (in reality more than that, see above). 

Summary: This is one of those games where Steam should have more than just an up vote or down vote. In some ways it is great but other super frustrating. 

I came for the puzzles, story and dark but beautiful art, not the crappy controls and limited perspectives. If you could save anywhere it would be much more bearable. Starting over again and again and then having to get back to where you were gets old after a few times.

I can't recommend because of the frustration. 

I can recommend it for everything else. Hopefully when I play Little Nightmares 2 it will play better.

I really liked the monsters in this game along with the backrounds and scenery. One of my favorite levels was the kitchen, especally when both of the chefs chase you. But i have two bad things to say. One is the fact that the final level, the lady`s quarters, is very short. And that there is about 100 different spots you can fall to your death on like stairs without railings. Other than that though i really enjoyed this game.

An excellent puzzle-platformer game, with beautiful scenery, astounding music and great horror elements.
As a guy that loves this type of games (went through the game twice now since I was about to play LN2 so I wanted to remember the story) I am rating this a 10/10 experience for it's type.
Amazing. Just amazing, simply beautiful. Can't wait to see what's next.

Brilliant game!

Plot, level and sound design are just perfect.
Cinematography is astonishing, especially in terms of lighting.
OST is just beautiful.
Every aspect of the game sets the mood perfectly at any time.

The controls responsiveness suits the slowish small-jump platforming style perfectly and they never feel clunky.
The partially fixed camera perspective may prove a little challenging for some at the beginning, but as soon as your depth notion adjusts it becomes quite easy to run through platforms with precision. Floor patterns help.
Definitely meant to be played with a controller and if so I doubt anyone will feel frustrated with controls for too long. 

Main game is in fact short, but the collectibles and achievements will keep it interesting for quite a few playthroughs and all DLCs combined are probably longer than the base game itself.

Definitely recommended, wouldn't change a thing, straight to my top favourite games of all times.
Looking forward to playing 2!
The puzzles are pretty much the same and not enjoyable. I couldn't stand to finish the game. I regret to playing this game.

The only word I can think of is "exquisite". The haunting gothic style is just amazing. Nothing in the game so far really scary but it's quite psychologically disturbing and always to keep you on edge the whole time. Very clever design. 

Your job is to guide a small feeble creature, I guess projection of yourself as a child, through the maze of what appears to be the bowels of a ship, there are lots of small puzzles, traps and a myriad of routes to cover on your journey. 

What amazed me most was that everything just take a little thought, there's no really tough puzzles to handle you just have to think a little bit. You're kept in constant suspense as to cross from room to room. The viewpoint often changes just a little and takes a tiny of adjustment wash time you enter and exit rooms. 

The whole game is an exercise in the unpleasant nightmares we have all endured sometimes as kids. I well remember many of these elements from my own childhood nightmares, darkened spaces, not able to escape from monsters very easily and the whole eerie nature of your vivid but limited imagination as a child. 

A superb game which I'm really enjoying.

The world of Little Nightmares is unparalleled. The atmosphere and the soundtrack crafts a superb story with no dialog. A creepy cute masterpiece that has me wanting to play again and again as I yearn for more.

pretty nice game bit weird that all the adults chase and try to kidnap you, you being a child but other than that the gameplay and the combined fact that my mate's dad is a chef in the game, pretty cool. 9.9/10 reason it's not a full ten is because they could've added a secret golden blem somewhere.

This game was not as long as I expected, but shit, I really like it. The atmosphere is perfect. The sound is clean. Each section offers something different and plays different. The style of this game is not one I have ever seen, which is very nice.

I do have a lot of questions after beating it. How and why am I on this ship? Why do they seem to hate little tiny people in rain coats? Is this come sort of cruise from hell? The hell is going on? But to be honest, I don't really care if these questions are not answered. It would only add to the charm of the game if it all stayed a big mystery.

I honestly can't remember what I payed for this game. It may have been a bit too high for the length of play. But then again, this game has more polish that a shoe shiner on wall street. And even though I have beaten the main chapters, there seems to be more to the game...

Verdict
8 tiny gnomes out of 9

Loved how they handled the camera in this which allows you to look around enough to progress but always restricts your vision enough to keep you nervous about could be ahead or behind you.

Took me about 5 hours to complete.  So its not the longest game in the world.  But I also got it on sale for 5 bucks so I don't mind so much.  Definitely worth grabbing if it has peaked your interest, especially on sale.

Even I'm not that into horror games they do have that"something" that makes you want to play them and here is why:
* Excellent atmosphere
* Awesome sound effects - Yeah, using headphones does a difference
* Terrific graphs
* Intuitive game play and puzzles
* Intriguing story line

HOWEVER... the only thing I would change is the camera view. Yes, you may turn it left and right but that is not enough to understand the depth of the room making you fail at critical moves. Of course, after some trials you end up doing it right but perspective could have been better. 

End game is "wooow!" so I'm looking forward to get and play part II.

Cheers!

i'm a huge fan of the little nightmare series. i fell in love with this game as soon as i started playing. the design is beautiful and the lore is so intriguing. such a gorgeous game with such amazing atmosphere and fascinating antagonists. can be a little stressful at times, as there are quite a lot of fast-paced scenes. i'd really only say that the 3rd chapter can be difficult and rather stressful. i have gone on to complete this game fully, achievements and all, and am officially starting to get into speedrunning it! it is rather short (can be finished in less than 40min while little nightmares II can be finished from anywhere past an hour) but when i played it for the first time, i had no idea how to complete any of the minor puzzles and i did die quite a lot, so your first time playing can be multiple hours long like mine was! if you're interested in a little platforming, action, a little disturbing content (it is called little nightmares after all. although the horror scenes are minimal) then you should 100% give this a try!

Little Nightmares is an amazing game. This game is very visually appealing, story-rich, and a lot of fun. I typically don't like puzzle games but this game did it really well. It was just challenging enough that I enjoyed it but not enough that I had to look up guides. I also don't typically care for story in my games but I love the way this game presented it. There's not really any cut scenes and most of the story is told through the gameplay. The game's physics can at times be frustrating and my character got stuck a couple of times but I wouldn't say this game has many bugs. The game is also very short so I'd recommend buying this game on sale because it is expensive for the length. However, the game feels like the perfect length when you're playing it.

Tbh this game made me cry. But even when I didn't want to play it because I was scared I couldn't keep myself away from it because I wanted to know more about the story. At every turn this game has you holding your breath. Very great game!

Is it scary? Yes. Is it very frustrating? also yes. The game tries to be scary, and it succeeds in doing so just fine, but in the end all I could focus on was the annoingly long respawn time, and the fact that I died for dumb reasons. It was more annoing than scary to die. It's probably a good game, and it looked good. But I could not find the will to play it again, even when I tried so hard to like it.
It also doesn't explain the controls at all, and they are placed at terrible places. I certainly recommend first changing the controls before starting, as it takes away a lot of frustration.

Really liked the game at first because it's different from what I usually play, it has a great design and atmosphere, but at some point I found the controls (with keyboad) really limiting and frustrating, especially because there are lots of moments where you have to hurry and target a very specific place, and doing that while struggling with the keys is badly challenging. Maybe the controller version doesn't suffer from this problem, idk.

I found this game from Stupendium and Dan Bull's 'Tune Into the Madness' song video, and if you are looking for a horror game, do yourself a huge favor and BUY THIS ONE, IMMEDIATELY.

If I were to describe Little Nightmares in one word: Masterpiece. Absolute masterpiece.

The minute details, the graphics, the soundtrack, the character development, the absolute HORROR, the physical panic I felt whilst playing this was impressive.

I have NEVER been freaked out by anything in the horror-media realm, and I watch a LOT of horror.
but THIS? This got my heart racing.

For the FULL experience, I would HIGHLY recommend checking out SuperHorrorBro's youtube channel for theories, and for a deep dive into the storyline and monster's storylines.

This kind of moody, macabre atmosphere is sadly missing from the majority of supposed "horror" fiction.

The simple thrill of evading larger than life monsters is infinitely more compelling than shooting wave after wave of enemies.

The story of a lone survivor's transformation as they are relentlessly hunted is compellingly told (especially since the game is rather short and lacks any dialogue). The ending might be my favorite in any video game.

This game is very, very good. One of the games that you should play. It is highly atmospheric and scary and tense and ugly. It gives you that feeling of "I don't want to do what I know I have to do."

Also, dear reader, if you do decide to play this game, know that the game itself sucks. I mean, sometimes the camera angle is weird and you fall off, or the scripted enemy glitches weird and you die, or like, sometimes things are just bull crap, or the puzzle they want you to solve is not particularly obvious.

Some things to know: In chapter 2, there is a mechanic where you want to be quiet. As such, don't step on things and walk on carpets! I went through the entire chapter the first time not understanding that. In chapter 3, things are based more on sight, but you can still make sounds to get in trouble. 

In my opinion, play this game. But this is one of those games where if you get stuck for more than a few minutes, probably go look at the walkthrough (there are several good ones in the guides section!) and more than likely you will go "Oh I am so glad I did not spend all day trying to figure that out." 

Also, the achievements / hidden nomes / jars to break / stuff to do: This game is not impossible to get the achievements, but they are obnoxious. The nomes are pretty easy to do, as are the lights. There are some that are super easy. The one where you put all the food in the pot is extremely frustrating, and most of the ones in the DLC are not ones you will figure out or notice, so again, refer to a walkthrough if you want these (Again, some very good ones in the guides section). 

In summary, great game, I can't wait to play Little Nightmares 2, and I wish I had played it a long time ago. I ended up being mad at the game by the end of my first playthrough, but for some reason, the game was magical enough to make me want to play multiple times, including doing the speedrun / no death achievement. The game is not hard, but do not be surprised if you are just sort of frustrated by something that feels kind of bullcrap. But it's worth it. 

DLC - The DLC levels were pretty good, however, one thing to say here: OMG THE FIRST ONE HAS SOME ANNOYING MECHANICS. It's worth it, just keep reloading and you will get it, but I did not like it really. The story of it is amazing, you should not spoil it, you should play it. The base game story is great, and the DLC I was more meh on until the last bit and it is totally imo worth the few hours to play through it all.

Too little of a game with too many bugs. In one of the interviews they claimed they wanted to make "quality over quantity" for the reasoning on why it's so short, its hard to buy that reasoning when it suffers from bugs, camera issues, and enemies that have nearly identical behaviors throughout the game (the only enemies who are really different are the janitor and the final boss, all the others have basically the same tactics) If they had included the secrets of the maw dlc for free or had maybe two more areas, or even just explained the plot more directly, it would at least feel more cohesive. What you buy with this game is an aesthetically pleasing world to play through but it offers nearly nothing else. Gameplay is rather simple, the horror isn't very scary, and the plot is so open ended and interpretative that it can hardly be called a plot at all, leavin the whole experience somewhat hollow. Can't recommend as is.

Under no circumstances did I ever expect to be here.  Sure, I'd heard of Little Nightmares.  I've seen it around.  But I'd never read any reviews or watched any gameplay.  It didn't seem like my kind of game from the banner art.

Yet here is my Steam review after having completed it.

I decided to purchase Little Nightmares after viewing some of a Let's Play of Little Nightmares 2.  It was a puzzle-platform-adventure with a very dark theme.  I've played games like it before (LIMBO), but LN2 was so well done that I decided to play the first game for myself.  It was conveniently on sale, as the Lunar New Year Sale 2022 was ongoing.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/LIMBO/

Little Nightmares definitely looks like it was made before Little Nightmares II.  The production values aren't as high, but the things that fascinated me about LN2 were still there.  This game combines feelings of grotesque, cute, exciting, shocking, and mysterious.  There were moments of slowly sneaking, and moments of running for my dang life.

The girl I played as never said a word, showed her face or revealed any of her many secrets, but I genuinely felt affection for her and wanted to help her through this journey.  The way she is animated is so masterfully done that it was enough to build that connection for me.  Animation quality and detail is generally a strength of this experience, though Little Nightmares 2 was even better.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/860510/Little_Nightmares_II/

I lead the girl to death many times in this.  The game does have some challenge and isn't always obvious.  But death is expected, and after returning to a checkpoint (generously placed), the girl calmly gets up from an apparent rest.  Such a great touch!

That Let's Play that I watched is the only reason I overcame my assumption that Little Nightmares was just some game that would be of little interest to me.  I was wrong to have ignored it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CJ5L_RTXpr4&list=PLYkzrVLtM-oC_yGedT_xQEiRjKm-9nQyL&index=1

Little Nightmares was extremely short, but I have recently gained an appreciation for games that offer brief, but complete and satisfying, experiences.  I had purchased the Complete Edition, so I have a few more levels I can play next.  Great game!


Post-script: I experienced this game in stereoscopic 3D with my virtual reality headset.  This was possible with the vorpX VR injection application, which  has a built-in profile for it.  I usually only play games with vorpX if geometry 3D mode works correctly, but I found that Little Nightmares looked pretty good with the Adaptive 3D mode.  In fact, this is the first time I have ever used Adaptive 3D or Z-Normal with vorpX.

To be clear, I did not experience Little Nightmares with immersive VR.  I played it as if it was on a giant screen 6 feet away from me.  Even so, being able to perceive the depth of characters and the game world added a lot to my enjoyment.  2.5D platformers look surprisingly great in stereoscopic 3D.

I feel like this game is often overlooked, I've seen a good couple of reviews call it an alright platformer with good art and not much else going for it, but I can't help but disagree. The gameplay alone is pretty engaging and, but I feel a lot of people ignore the really well done silent storytelling on display in this game. It's also got an artstyle unlike many other games I've played, the closest I can think of might be American McGee's Alice Returns. Overall a solid game with an intriguing plot, good gameplay and beautiful art.

Clumsy controls, unclear objectives and punishing resets quickly obscure the beauty of Little Nightmares.

This game as a whole is a great experience, the visuals, the music, the atmosphere, the exploration, it has combined all of these aspects to make a unique game which makes you want to immerse yourself in the world. Unfortunately before I bought this game I watched a plot review which spoiled a bit of the plot and game play, but I still felt driven to purchase it for myself and play it. I recommend going in blind and learning things for yourself, it makes a good difference. Even considering what I already knew before there were many things I discovered which I really enjoyed and that surprised me. This game feels like a passion project and I will definitely be playing little nightmares 2! I highly recommend. The only issue I've had is even though the perspective is what really makes the game unique (and I enjoy it from an aesthetic sense) sometimes it is hard to judge movement and jumps and such, but it is not a huge issue.

[h1]LITTLE NIGHTMARES[/h1]
[b]tl;dr[/b]

Rating: Good
Clear Time: 3 hours
100% Time: 5+ hours
Summary: A unique take on the spoopy genre, this puzzle platformer creeps you out and looks great doing so. Unfortunately the controls and movement are the true horror of this game but they don't take enough away from how interesting the game is.

[i][b][u]What is it?[/u][/b][/i]
A creepy "2D" puzzle platformer where you take control of a small child in a very dark an ominous place interacting with objects to hopefully escape the grotesque monsters around you. I say "2D" because you can run both towards and away from the camera to explore but ultimately you'll be running left/right.

[i][b][u]What I Liked[/u][/b][/i]
The game has the whole "show, don't tell" methodology. There's a small intro cutscene, then you wake up in a suitcase and that's the entire story you're given. It's the environments and the objects that are meant to tell the story and I think it does a good job. The game also doesn't rely on cheap scares; infact this game (to me) is NOT a horror game as it isn't intended to spook you, it's only meant to creep you out and make you curious. Otherwise, the game looks fantastic and the environments are a joy to explore. The soundtrack is fantastic and at a short playtime of 3~ hours it doesn't overstay it's welcome.

[i][b][u]What I Didn't Like[/u][/b][/i]
The biggest problem of this game is the depth perception. Because you can run towards/away from the camera you will often get a false sense of position: jumping to grab onto to a ledge only to realise your character was not at all in line with it. This happens ALOT in multiple instances. You're also going to [b]constantly[/b] get stuck on objects and the corners of objects which especially sucks during chases; it feels like the hitboxes of inanimate objects are larger than the object. There's one section at the end of Chapter 3 (out of 5) where you have a split second to line yourself up for a jump onto a moving object. Most of my deaths in this game were from missing that jump because the camera angle is so wonky it's impossible to line yourself up. There is also a few unskippable story moments that throw off the pace of the game but there's only 5, they're annoying after your first playthrough.

[i][b][u]What I Would Add/Change[/u][/b][/i]
Some meaningful collectables would have been nice. Notes written by inhabitants that explore more of who they are, or notes on the environment, anything world related would be fantastic. I wouldn't change anything although I wish the above issues would be fixed.

[i][b][u]Personal Thoughts[/u][/b][/i]
I liked the game alot, and if I knew how short it was I would have completed it in one sitting. I don't know if i'll play the second but this game definitely does something unique and I have to give it props. I found trying to speedrun the game more fun than the base game; knowing what is coming up gives you time to explore the environments more thoroughly instead of wandering around thinking about how lost you are.

[i][b][u]Achievements[/u][/b][/i]
Easy except one. Most rely on completing the game/getting collectibles/interacting with certain objects. The only hard achievement is to complete the game in under an hour without dying. This would be much easier if the depth perception didn't make you jump into a pit 100 times forcing you to start again. I read guides saying it was tough and you'd only barely make it at best, but I clocked in at 45 minutes so it I had alot of time to spare!
it's a nice change from jumpscares, to a really well thought out and portrayed atmospheric horror. it's executed wonderfully, and i can't wait to play the second when i get a new pc!

Amazing game! The visuals and music are outstanding, and personally I love the gameplay. I wouldn't say it is incredibly scary, but I don't think that is what they were going for. It has an incredibly well done creepy and mysterious atmosphere that has you questioning who the real "bad guys" of the story are. Despite there being no dialogue, the mystery of everything going on is incredibly captivating and has you speculating as you play. My only real complaint is the final chapter is very short compared to the others, and as a result you don't get to see the enemy associated with that chapter all that much. Also, the controls can be a little finicky at times, but you get used to them after a bit. These are only minor problems in the end though.

Don't skip out on this phenomenal experience, even if you aren't into horror games very much. You'll still find lots of enjoyment in the narrative and puzzles!

Since the puzzles and action challenges are too simply designed to make this a puzzle game or action platformer, highlights are supposed to be found in the story and graphics. However, I only see beauty in the consistent grim environment and character design. The story is so obscure that has no meaningful insights to be told. The developer did not even try to explain those mysteries throughout the game. Some people like obscure plots cause they seem to have some deep thoughts behind. But the most common situation is that there is no thought at all. I feel like the developers just drew some strange monsters and characters as well as some grim maw and then stitched them together without thinking the reasons of the relationships between characters and why they fit. So basically, I think this game is for children who do not want it too hard and do not care about the story.

I'd say 7/10 the game itself is amazing, the story is enjoyable with added DLC that links to the original, the design is amazing and I like the atmosphere too but there is a lack of key indicators that let the player move comfortably through the story ( like giving subtle nudges as to where to start with certain puzzles ) and the mechanics aren't the best either - I noticed you can interact with certain things but sometimes not others of the same variety - sometimes when Six needs to grab onto something it will either just flat out fail, teleport the player in an odd fashion, or if you're really unlucky grab whatever you're needing to grab but for some off reason you're unable to climb it so  you have to redo everything or fall to your death. I love the game, it's not bad in any way besides it could be a smoother experience with game-play. I think it's worth picking up on a Sale and checking out - you're not going to find much out there like this, just be aware you may have some frustrating moments here and there dealing with semi-clunky game-play.

While this game is a Horror title I will say that it's not extremely scary, I feel it's more of a Psychological Horror. It keeps you on your toes anticipating a scare. Being chased by some of the creatures definitely gets your blood pumping (specifically the janitor and the hoard of hungry people). The puzzles are relatively easy. I only got stuck on a couple of them. I couldn't stop playing until I beat the entire game. I'm considering beating it to 100% completion. Overall, Little Nightmares is a great game and i'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys platformers, puzzles, and horror games. 8.5/10

A game about a little Swedish girl running for her life from typical American Wall-Mart customers. 

As much as I want to give it a thumbs up it's ultimately a poor man's INSIDE. The art is visually amazing but feels like a low hanging fruit conceptually with lore that forcefully attempts to feel 'deep'. The game design itself is severally lacking. Game-wise it's just a platforming game with poor mechanics and almost no puzzle elements. An annoying checkpoint system makes you cross redundant sections instead of restarting from where the action should start. It's a 6/10-7/10 in my book but Steam ratings skew it to seem like an exceptionally good game, which it's not. Get it if discounted or free.

Great concept with intriguing environment design. Mechanics are very similar to the grossly underappreciated ICO from the early PS2 days, with the main objective to navigate from one room and area to the next, minus the need for battle (which is other a plus or a minus, depending on your perspective). No real story and some of the challenges are fairly simplistic but the controls are intuitive and the atmospheric visuals and character models are quite beautiful. More experienced gamers will probably beat it pretty quickly (around 4-6 hours) but it's a fun ride while it lasts and there's always the extra DLC level content if you purchased the special edition.
very good game it impress me a lot

This is a super fun game. Got my adrenaline pumping the whole time and had a lot of fun with it. Little to no gore, and nothing outright terrifying like in your face jump scares, but it is a horror game for sure. Very eerie atmosphere, always keeps you thinking about what you need to do next and keeps your brain moving to make smart moves or learn from your mistakes. Allows some exploring for the cool hidden achievements and collectibles, which is really fun. It's like a big hide and seek from monsters that always had me anxious to go around the next corner. Highly recommend. I bought the DLC and played all of it after I finished the story, and I have to say, I actually teared up a bit. Another beautiful thing about this game is the story. Sure, most of it is up in the air for people's personal interpretations, but I find it a very intriguing and meaningful story. Highly recommend the DLC once you finish the main story so you can get more insight on a lot of things and find out even more about the characters and the Maw.

Absolutely phenomenal game and whimsically atmospheric; there's so much to love about this game, the storyline, the sombre soundtrack and the style of arts is just wonderfully beautiful. Despite the game being super sombre and all, I thought the tones and colours chosen for the game really add that that "vibrancy" to it while still maintaining the element of creepiness that runs throughout the whole game. 

My only real problem with the game is the WASD mechanic is so frustratingly fiddly and awkward in some situation, i.e. I really have to be standing at specific angle to be able to perform a task like grabbing onto things; timing is also super important in this time, in my opinion --then again, this could very well be due to my non-agile fingers and the few mini heart attacks I suffered while trying to make my escape.

Overall, I enjoyed this time so much and I'm looking forward to playing part II soon :)

Once again Tarsier delivers a game which is 1) unique in style and 2) full of cute/ugly ragdolls. This time they chose to fight on the same level as Playdead (known for Limbo/Inside), but did they succeed? Let me be very clear with you: I believe they succeeded at creating something unique, but not at doing something as good and meaningful as Inside (which is a little masterpiece of analysis and sense). Little Nightmares (which is a terrible title) is a kind of typical dark tale of children abuse and monstrous ogres, played in a 2.5D puzzle platformer exactly like Inside, made of stealth, chase and terror. The scenario is dark and gory, without any surprise: the building up is so obvious that you just fear to reveal a truth you already guess. The platform is alright, nothing very new, and sadly sometimes a bit buggy (guessing where the depth of the 2D is makes it a chore sometimes). The visuals are fantastic, as always with Tarsier: a mix of ultra realism (the textures!!) and dark fantasy (Burton/Psychonauts style). Music is discrete and fine, scenario is gloom and okay.
However, look at my playtime: it took me less than 5 hours to finish the game (without getting the hidden goodies of course). That is very short... and there is nothing to analyze like in Inside when you are done. Actually, when I was done, I thought "so... what was the big story? that does not answer anything" and looked at the chapters... 3 of them were locked... you guessed it, because I had to buy DLCs. I do not believe this is a proper thing to do. If I have to buy 3 DLCs or even Little Nightmares 2 to understand the story, then they failed in narrative skill what they achieved in mercantile scheme. I might purchase the follow up later, hopefully they put more content into it.
Still! if you can get it on big sale, and feel like a little dark tale for an evening, Little Nightmares is still an enjoyable little game.

Great little short game and even shorter for speed runners since there is an achievement for finishing in under an hour. I've waited about a year to play this game (for my own reason) and it was worth the wait. Anyways here are some pros and cons from my POV.
Pros:
1. Amazing atmosphere. 
2. Solid game play 
3. Fun DLCs.
4. Short and sweet.
Cons:
1. No written story. (who is this little nightmare? what is with the "people" and the ship?)
2. Game crashed when i died on the DLC and I could only access the DLCs (with the little boy) through stage selection.
3. Too short (game is great but when you are encouraged to finish it in 60 minutes for an achievement, what does that say about the price for the game & DLCs)
4. No replay value. (Honestly after i finish the DLCs its going to be an automatic uninstall for me)
This game is the perfect mix of cute and creepy! If you're a horror fan who's looking for a compelling story, Little Nightmares is the game for you.

One of my favourite indie games ever!
The story revolves around six, a young child who must venture through the vessel known as the Maw and must try and escape the horrors that lie within it. The characters are so well designed, making them look as if they have more to hide more than their creepy exterior has to offer. The story itself is really nice as it allows for the player to make their own interpretation about the on goings of the ship while giving a vague narrative to move the story along. 
The setting of the Maw is really impressive as it may contain the main departments that a ship would have, but twists them into its own visual design and keeps the player guessing on what will come next. From the Kitchen where the chefs reside, to the main food hall that the visitors devour in, each area really compliments the enemies that come with it and adds to their characters and mystery that itself may hold. I also love the fact that the settings are held in doll house like sections which adds more to the child like nature of the game.
Visually, its stunning as the imagery is done in a Tim Burton-esque style with it being really creepy, but also childlike in its essence. Graphically, the game is really impressive with the lighting being on point and the textures being high quality for the player to examine themselves. 
Sound and Audio are superb as the Soundtrack really adds to the atmosphere and is made to feel nightmare-ish with it being dream-like. The audio as well is fantastic as the sounds of enemies, them chasing you, and Six's interactions with objects feeling authentic and fit the overall theme of the game. 
In terms of gameplay, its really fun to control. The main thing you will be doing is traversing around the Maw, using object to help progress through the story and hiding/running away from enemies. The game is done in a 2.5D style which i though was going to be tedious in terms of platforming, but turned out to be really smooth and easy to navigate around. Jumping, running and grabbing are really nicely done as well and it doesn't feel like any of them are lacking or under performing than other mechanics. The enemies in this game have their own mechanics and ways of capturing you, such as the Janitor with his long arms and his sense of hearing instead of sight. The one thing i really wish was for this game to be longer as i really had a great time experiencing and just wanted more. 
Overall, Little Nightmares is a brilliant indie game that, even thought i got it on sale, i would have payed full price for an experience such as this and i would highly recommend it to everyone wanting a gripping horror/thriller experience.

Not a word, only a hush. The terror you feel as you [u]tiptoe through a haunted and dampen world of absurd dimensions and proportions[/u] is an [b]incomparable impression[/b] that you get from the [i]Little Nightmares[/i].

You play with a petite character with limited control, discovering a world of wordless stories. The [b]endless desire to explore the corners keeps you captivated[/b], as you do your best to maintain undetected by the stomping or sulking opponents.

Make sure to enjoy this particularly hunting, yet a delightful tale. [b][i]Little Nightmares[/i] truly stands out in its genre of puzzle-platformers and horror games[/b]; yet the creators prefer to label it as a ''suspenseful adventure,'' which it frankly is, as there are no jump scares or cheap thrills.

If the game separately wasn't sufficient, [u]the DLC series, ''Secrets of The Maw'', [b]add a unique twisting and meaning to the initial story[/b][/u]. If you wept in awe on the ending of the main story, this one will make it far worse.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Atmospheric and beautifully realized, [i]Little Nightmares[/i] combines some solid platforming with an environment that breeds dread without resorting to cheap scares. While pretty short in length, the game packs in a good variety of scenes, narrative, and characters to keep each level fresh, challenging, and unique.

[h1]Six Michelin Stars[/h1]
I think the thing [i]Little Nightmares[/i] does best is it's ability to send the player through a revolving door of mechanics while never feeling repetitive. It nails the pacing between nail-biting boss encounters and slower-paced puzzle sections; when to close in on the player to force quick reactions and when to hang back and let the player drink in the scenery. Trial-and-error is still your primary tool for learning how to progress through the game, though the difficulty has been turned way down. If you're looking for a die-hard puzzler, this isn't going to be your game. [i]Little Nightmares[/i] has turned a lot of the hurdles of puzzle-platform and replaced them with speed bumps so that the player can progress at a reasonable rate while still having enough challenges to overcome so the game isn't just a walking simulator.

If I had to make a comparison, I'd say that if you took [i]LIMBO[/i], gave it an element of depth, and turned down the puzzle while upping the atmosphere, then you get something remarkably similar to [i]Little Nightmares[/i]. Indeed, the gameplay is remarkably similar to many other entries in the "small child scary world" genre of Indie games. However, while the gameplay explores no new fronts, it's undeniable to extra time and attention when towards crafting a grotesque but visually fascinating world for you to explore.

[h1]Breakdown[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[olist]
    [*][b]Bad Dreams:[/b] [i]Little Nightmares[/i] features some excellent checkpoint systems throughout the game. Deaths never set you back too far so that forward momentum keeps going.
    [*][b]Lights & Nomes:[/b] The game has two sets of hidden "collectibles", lanterns to light and Nomes to hug, that really rewards players exploring the environment without being excessively challenging to get.
[/olist]
[b]Cons[/b]
[olist]
    [*][b]Twitchy Legs:[/b] The nature of the game and controls means that precision platforming is quite inconsistent and the few sections that relied on precise movement (such as one section running across a table) was quite frustrating.
    [*][b]Sticky Fingers:[/b] A sort of weird decision in terms of controls, but the fact that the player needs to constantly hold grab for Six to grab a hold of ledges was quite annoying since in most platformers characters will automatically grab on to ledges or ladders or environment set-pieces when appropriate.
[/olist]

[b]Score[/b]: 7.5/10
