A glorified walking simulator, whilst being a frustrating atmospheric puzzle platformer with tedious quick time like events and fetch quests - I have finished the game.

Yes, the visuals a good, the soundtrack is good... but that's about it. The puzzles are quite lacklustre, escape sequences are annoying and the platforming is very clunky. It's not scary at all, just atmospheric. Getting one-shot by every mob is also annoying, especially with the ill placed auto save / checkpoint system. You may find you have to do an entire area again because you made a tiny mistake, like being a split second late to press a button. The puzzles are very basic, climb up this, go through there, fetch this, place this here - nothing innovative and interesting at all; basically a glorified fetch quest. As for the platforming, you have to time your jumps and angles correctly, otherwise you'll fall and restart. The camera sometimes skews itself, which makes moving even harder, especially during escape sequences and when walking on thin platforms. Often on these thin platforms, you don't know which button to press because if you keep holding it in down, you'll fall off, so you need to hold down two buttons and do this weird dance to stay in the middle.

I can see why people can like this, if you can somehow forgive all the bad gameplay mechanics. You'll like this game if you're a big fan of platformers, you like a little adventure, and through in some puzzles here and there. In a way, it's like a cinematic, with extra steps. However, I don't recommend the game. There are much better platformers, much better puzzle games etc. out there.

Good little game :)
I'm recommending the game but it comes with a big caveat, so first a WARNING: It's very short! I finished it in about 4 hours but I've seen speed runs of it under 40 minutes. Do not buy this at it's full $29.99 price. Despite everything else about the game being great at $29.99 it's not good value for money. Get it on sale when it's between $5 and $10 instead.

Now, for the good parts.
First, the visuals, it's beautiful. It has the look and feel of a Tim Burton movie. The level of horror is also pretty much on par with something like Nightmare Before Christmas so if you're not into horror games, don't let the game's title deter you. It's creepy, atmospheric and fascinating.
The sounds of the game bring it to life. Directional sound is a must so I recommend headphones.
The game is also meant to be played using a controller so it's definitely recommended. I played it with mouse and keyboard and definitely died quite a few needless deaths because of it.

There is no dialogue in the game but the story it tells is great and seeing as this is mostly a kind of quick time platformer the journey is the most important thing the game offers. In that department it really shines taking you on a suspense filled ride through a beautiful and creepy setting as a seemingly harmless and vulnerable little humanoid.
The story also contains a clear message about greed and comes with its own, intriguing little twist ending.

It's definitely a worthy and unique experience. 7/10

Little Nightmares presents itself in the form of a 2.5D platformer with distinct elements of stealth, survival and uncertainty.

With little need for dialogue, Little Nightmares successfully tells a horrific story worthy of empathy and acclamation. The ghoulish lore sets the tone for top-notch gameplay right from the opening moments through the DLC expansions, which tell an interleaving tale of their own.

The eerie art style and sound have been masterfully crafted to seamlessly immerse the player inside [i]The Maw – an underwater vessel inhabited by corrupted souls looking for their next meal.[/i] The environments instil the fear factor organically.

The gameplay is comparable to that of INSIDE, but with relatively simpler environmental puzzles and refreshing mechanics. The game is rather short and plays optimally with a controller.

Overall, Little Nightmares is definitely worthy of recommendation. I would suggest getting the [i]Complete Edition[/i] that comprises the game and the [i]Secrets of The Maw Expansion Pass[/i] which would get you the story DLC and would support the brilliant minds over at Tarsier Studios.
As a whole, Little Nightmares is up there sharing the throne with INSIDE, and is a genre-defining experience in itself.

[h1]Preface[/h1]
My viewers recommended a bunch of horror games to me especially after how bad I felt Layers of Fear was, but knowing my own personality, and that I don’t get scared very easily (which isn’t very good streaming for most horror games…) I decided among the suggestions to go for a more story oriented rather than jumpscare and react kind of games, settling on this after seeing the trailer.

[h1] Review [/h1]
Little Nightmares is a story puzzle platformer with a very unsettling atmosphere.
 
Its art style is realistic but slightly off, with the entire environment easily understood, but there’s always just something that’s a bit off. This along with the constant movement of the screen (spoilers) leaves the player feeling uneasy, and even with your guard up, tends to make you unsettled. For this, I can applaud them, but fear is not exactly something I feel in this game.

The platforming is very simple and easy to grasp making this a great pick up and play immediately without having to spend quite a lot of time learning the controls, the movement, if a tad bit floaty and the lack of camera makes some jumps a bit hard to judge. It does at times feel a bit of a nuisance, as there is a specific puzzle [url=https://clips.twitch.tv/HardArtisticYamOneHand-uv7RIbzKR7GxIi1E] Mild Spoiler [/url] that basically had me trapped for 10 or so minutes, this, along with one of the last ‘run’ scenes are the kind of pacing issues that I feel go badly in horror games, as it takes you out of the experience very quickly. However with those as exceptions, most of the puzzles are very well crafted and intuitive, it requires basically no handholding at all because of its amazing game design, with usual and subtle hints that make you feel clever more so than following around a ‘quest’ or pointer.

Since this is more of a one of kind of game, with little replayability, it’s better to not talk much at all about the story, though one thing to note is the heavy emphasis on themes. Spirited Away fans, please pick this game up. I swear it’s worth it for the references alone. 

There is also a point in the game if you have basically any pattern recognition, that you can very very easily predict what will happen, but that does not do anything to soften the blow at all. It’s that kind of building up of characters, that don’t even speak, impressive.

(6/10) Decent as a game, mediocre for the genre, redeemed only by lack of jumpscare and decent atmosphere

The base game is excellent and a must play if you've enjoyed Limbo and Inside. It's short, clocking in at about 3h, but certainly worth it. Controls do feel clunky and unresponsive at times, depth perception is an issue, and some of the puzzles are a bit vague, but I'd say the eerie dollhouse aesthetic and overall feel of the game outweigh the negative.

The DLC, on the other hand, I'm less positive about. It's often far from clear what you have to do to progress the game, and oftentimes I found myself looking at a walkthrough for hints, simply because I felt I needed to do something different. The clunky controls also make The Residence a bit of a chore as you'll have to face enemies "Alan Wake"-style.

[quote]💬 [i]“Are they the giants, or am I playing as a 30-week-old fetus wearing a yellow raincoat?”[/i][/quote]

[h1][b]🚀 Overview[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[table]
[tr]
[th]👍 Merits[/th]
[th]👎 Flaws[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
✔️ Interesting universe

✔️ Charming art style

✔️ Spiffing audio design

✔️ Pure child abuse

✔️ Encourages cannibalism
[/td]
[td]
❌ Story hidden for unknown reason

❌ Aweful camera angles at times

❌ Not very good controls

❌ Random crashes & glitches
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]


[h1][b]🚪 Introduction[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
A sandbox story is a category I use to classify games with the likes of LIMBO. When a game presents characters through silhouette forms with nearly no information about what's happening around them, it all hinges on the player's imagination, based on his interpretation of the provided barebone elements in the coalescence. In other words, the player comes out with a story modeled by his own fiction derived from his experience in the game. At first glance, I thought that Little Nightmares shares the same concept, but after a deep dive into it, it seems that I was mistaken.


[h1][b]🎮 Single-player[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[b]💠 Where Is the Plot?[/b]

It's inside a hidden pot. After an oracular intro, the game starts; things go on with no clear source for valid information. You're playing with many questions roaming your mind. You don't know a thing about the protagonist or her role in the story. So? Will everything unwrap at the end? Nah, the curtain falls, and still, I don't have a clue. Is it a Sandbox story? I asked myself. Let's search the internet to be sure. WOW! There is a Little Nightmare universe, and its characters have names and vital roles in it. Additionally, I've learned that the protagonist's name is Six from an external site after I've completed the game for the second time; heh, imagine that!

[b]💠 Raconteurs[/b]

How did you get all this info then? There are 2 storytellers: the first being the little details in the game's environment, and the second one is [url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=eu.bandainamcoent.LNDC&hl=en&gl=US][b]Little Nightmares Comics[/b][/url]. After connecting the comics with the game, it comes out as a very compelling tale. Why not include the comics in the base game? Doing so could've avoided impairing the experience. Comics based on games work well when they add extra details that weren't there before, not present an entire story that should've been there in the first place.

[b]💠 The Little Nightmares[/b]

There are fascinating details that create hints related to the main plot, but they're all prone to false or inaccurate theories. The death mechanism in this game carries a brilliant meaning to it. Every time you die, you restart from checkpoint as Six waking up from a bad dream. It means every death that happens is just a nightmare for Six when she takes a resting nap before actually going to that place. It weaves the entire story of Six as a death-free adventure full of little nightmares that wake her up from resting naps to continue going on.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2614831239
[b]💠 The Unknown Little Journey[/b]

You play as a little girl in a cryptic world, where everyone wants to eat her for some reason. Maybe she's a delicious and nutritious humanoid living candy? Who knows? Anyway, this game is weird enough. Basically, your gameplay consists of platforming, solving straightforward puzzles that do their best to seem clever, and some creepy chasing action. Mostly, puzzles revolve around: platforming, searching for items to advance progression, and stealth sections. In addition, there are collectibles like breaking statues, hugging Nomes, finding message-carrying bottles (DLC), and lighting lanterns; finding them will unlock concept arts and the Rascal Mask. The campaign may take you roughly 3 to 4 hours to complete, assuming it's your first time.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2615111333

[h1][b]🛠️ Technical[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[b]💠 Big Nightmares[/b]

The irrational relative scaling between objects and characters creates a creepy art style that stands in the middle of being realistic and cartoonish. You see the protagonist, a nine-year-old girl, as tall as a bottle of wine; oversized freakish humans with ugly faces and preternatural postures; objects that fit the protagonist's hands and others that go well in size with the freakish beings. It creates an ambiguous capturing atmosphere that defies logic but gives the game a distinctive artistic taste. Add excellent lighting and sound design to the mix, and here you have a sublime audio-visual flavor.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2627206913
[b]💠 Is It Raining?[/b]

No. So why are you wearing a raincoat? You'll uselessly confine yourself with it. It's the same as confining a 3D platforming game through stupid camera angles. Sure, you can pan the camera to look around the fixed angle, but still, it doesn't help much when your character is not in the same line with the targeted platform. You'll feel this problem when you fail a jump between platforms, slide to the wall instead of its crawlway during a chase, fail to maintain a straight movement on a narrow board. All these misses will make you look like a complete jackass, BTW. Also, if Six gets behind an object, she becomes offscreen, where you control her blindly.

[b]💠 Parkinson’s Patient[/b]

Adding insult to injury, controlling Six can get unresponsive at times, where you need to hit the button multiple times for her to respond or grab something. It happens very few times but can lead to maximum frustration on certain occasions. Maintaining a balanced run on narrow platforms can be annoying with the WSAD keys; an analog stick is a much better option for this task. I strongly recommend playing this game with a controller. In terms of game performance, unfortunately, I've encountered 5 random crashes with a fatal error message as well as a few annoying glitches.


[h1][b]⚖️ Verdict[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
I am very disappointed; I expected a masterpiece. At first, I wasn't going to recommend Little Nightmares, but I think it deserves a try. Its appealing art style, decent sound design, and compelling hidden [spoiler]story[/spoiler] saved it from drowning. I hope that other games sharing this captivating universe offer a much better experience than this.

A wonderfully dark, wonderfully weird little labour of love. I play a lot of games, and it takes a lot for horror games to affect me, in any way really, be it shock, awe, fear or disgust. Most games have glimmers of the magic, but rarely manage to pull a full reaction out of me. Little Nightmares has several of those moments, and in such a short game that's an achievement. 

If you want a seat of your pants, squeaky-bum anxiety inducing platformer, then this game is perfect for you. It manages to be terrifying, horribly eeire, and utterly engrossing, and all without a single line of dialog. It's environments are escher'esqé, redolent of the darker work of Tim Burton, and it's puzzles are challengingly simple, but effective at making you think. It's main character, the child you play as, is... Complex, for a little mute monster. And it's monsters are just the right amount of utterly repulsive. Most of them, anyway. The last one is just creepy. 

Just play it. It's a surreal journey, and well worth full price, so if you get it on sale then it's a steal.

Overall fun and full of character.

The controls sometimes let it down but that's a symptom of the genre, rather than a technical problem with this title.

You'll probably die quite often but the checkpoints are generous so feel free to play it like a trial-and-error game.

I love a game that can tell a story w/o needless dialog that goes on and on. I also love a good puzzle game that adds element other than pure puzzle, which generally enhances the game. 3rdly, if that's a word, I like games that are gruesome and games that turn reality up on it's head and scream at you THIS ISN'T RIGHT, the person that made this isn't right in the head. It doesn't have to be gory and bloody (although I prefer it personally), it just has to grab you and shake the shit out of you. Games that make you stop and say WTF. 

This game game does that! Originally I thought this game was kind of for kids due to the main character being portrayed as a 'little kid running around in a grown up world'. But very early on in the game you see that it isn't for kids. Instead, in my opinion, one of the most disturbing games I've played in 20 years. 

Again, I'd like to point out that the entire story line is done with visuals...and not a big long back story that weaves in and out and has a bunch of crazy twists and turns. The amazing story is all unveiled in front of your face.  BEAUTIFULLY done! I cannot wait to play v2 and, if you haven't, you should too.

Little Nightmares is a game I thought was going to be similar to Limbo and Inside. I was wrong. They both share some similarities; they have an ambiguous story and awesome atmosphere. But gameplay-wise, while those games are 2D, this one is 2.5D. It has 3D movement, but depth is limited, so you mostly play on a 2D plane. Of course, that doesn’t make a game bad.
But the controls are awful. First off, some actions are binded awkwardly on the controller. Secondly, a lot of times you want to do something, but the game says no to you, especially during trickier jumps, grabbing stuff or ledges or carrying objects. And while I can appreciate the game for what it is, I can’t deny all the frustration I had because of poor controls.
The game is short, clocking around 3 hours, but the DLC combined adds another 3 hours (yes, the DLC is as big as the main game). But it’s intense. It has exploration, platforming, puzzle-solving, hide-and-seek and escape sections. It’s very good at creating tension. The DLC is harder but makes up for an easier main game.
Despite the controls, I can recommend the Complete Edition on sale. It can get frustrating at times, but it’s a good experience overall. Just don’t expect a Limbo or Inside clone, or you’ll be disappointed.

[i]Little Nightmares[/i] is a 2.5D horror game where you run around utilizing your basic platforming and puzzle-solving skills. The art style is somewhat cartoon-like in a way, though that may not be the right word, and it helps paint a weirdly grotesque view for the horrors you come across.

People seem to commonly bring up [i]LIMBO[/i] and [i]INSIDE[/i]. It's clear the game has some inspiration from those games, but what's designed is a bit different.

The sound and music overall are strong in painting a creepy atmosphere, along with the difference in dimensions between yourself and everything else. You are so tiny while the rest of this world is large and looming, and you'll find distorted humans and other odd creatures.

The story of this game is not too clear. It's somewhat of a mystery though there are some metaphors you might be able to glean from what you find. The DLCs (particularly the last one) does answer a question or two that you might have had, but I would say that they're a bit weaker in quality because the first two retread some of the same areas and don't bring a whole lot new to the table. But it's still probably worth a run through those if you're interested.

And of course, there is [i]Little Nightmares II[/i] now, which I think is a very strong follow-up; but of course this is a review for the original, and you should definitely play this first, in any case.

The biggest problem I have with this game is some of the platforming sections, especially due to the depth of view with the camera. You may end up falling off places where it's hard to see your movement, and your interaction with some objects can be a bit finicky. But none of it is a dealbreaker by any means.

The last thing to note is that it's length is somewhere around 3 to 4 hours, depending upon your speed through places and if you do all of the collectibles. My overall playtime is from going back to get more collectibles and also doing a speedrun.

Altogether, I think you should give a quick glance at a screenshot or two, and maybe a part of the trailers, and that should tell you whether you're interested in the way this world looks. Then when you play and hear the proper audio alongside the visuals, that should hopefully reel you in.

I certainly enjoyed my time in this creepy world, and I was interested enough to go through its DLCs as well as the second game. I'd recommend most people to do the same.

Spoiler free
As I do with games I'm really interested in, I stay away from any and all promotional content (screenshots, photos, trailers, etc) to not be spoiled in the slightest. With that said, while playing Little Nightmares, I couldn't help but notice a strange familiarity I had towards it. And it's not from having played Limbo before, the two play completely different.

The controls are a bit wonky, but are easy to get used to. Graphics are stylized and visually stunning at times. Sound and music are superb. Credits are an unnecessarily long 15+ minutes (but that's what happens when your publisher is AAA and they feel the need to credit every one of their employees throughout the world. I'm looking at you too, EA).

While the game is creepy in its own right, some parts and sequences genuinely creeped me out.

Without revealing too much, definitely pick up this game if you can.
very fun game.  its not scary but definitely enjoyable. recommend 10/10

Works great with Proton. No issues at all in the main story. DLC isn't fully stable but restarting the game fixes issues on the rare occurrence of bugs, which may or may not be a Proton-related issue. 

Great atmospheric story based game. Gets the adrenaline going! I'm not usually interested in the horror genre, but quite enjoyed this one.
